column1: PHL445H1:Metalogic::36S:A continuation of  PHL345H1
column2: this is a course in the mathematical study of logic
column3: also known as metalogic. We will investigate and prove theorems about logical systems. Topics covered may include: important results in metalogic
column5: or lambda-calculus.:PHL345H1/ MAT309H1; 4.0 credits in philosophy:::PHL445H5;  PHLD51H3:Humanities:

column1: PHL446H1:Seminar in Decision Theory::36S:Decision theory studies what one ought to do when some more or less desirable outcomes of one’s actions depend on external facts about which one is uncertain. Uncertainty is characterized in terms of probabilities
column2: desires are characterized in terms of utilities
column3: and together they determine the expected utility of one’s actions. This course introduces these notions and their mathematical representations
column4: as well as critically reflects on philosophical questions such as whether one should always take the action that maximize one’s expected utility
column5: whether uncertainty is subjective or objective

PHL489Y1:Advanced Topics in Philosophy: Socrates Project:::Socrates Project Seminar. The Socrates Project Seminar allows exceptional senior undergraduate students to become teaching assistants for a 1st year PHL course. In addition to grading and leading tutorials
column2: Socrates Project students enroll in  PHL489Y1 as a condition of their employment. Students are expected to apply for the Socrates Project in March prior to the start of the Fall/Winter term. Admission to the Socrates Project is limited to students enrolled in a Philosophy or Bioethics program. A minimum of 80% in PHL courses is required. Information about the Socrates Project including the application form can be found at https://philosophy.utoronto.ca/st-george/undergraduate-at-st-george/socrates-project-undergraduate-tas/:Permission of the instructor and Department::::Humanities:

PHS100H1:Discovering Global Health::24L/24T:This course introduces students to basic public health-related concepts
column2: significant aspects of the historical development of global health
column3: and a selection of topics illustrating the broad and evolving nature of this field. In addition
column4: it helps students explore the contributions that various disciplines/fields offer to global health.:::::Social Science:

column1: PHS300H1:HIV Prevention Research::24L:This course examines HIV prevention research across the full spectrum of sciences concerned with prevention of HIV and sexual health
column10: and cultural theory. Examples are borrowed from efforts across the globe. The course highlights prevention research related to key populations at risk of HIV infection and transmission. The course focuses on challenges and issues
column11: with the goal of stimulating critical thinking and engagement with topics. Some material will be presented by Guest Lecturers who are experts in the areas
column12: allowing students to learn from and interact with these experts and to hear about their current research as well as their career paths. It is expected that at the end of this course students will have an advanced appreciation of the history and future and underlying values and ethics of effective HIV prevention research
column13: including future possibilities and challenges. One ancillary aim is to encourage students to compare and contrast HIV Prevention with prevention research in adjacent areas (e.g.

column1: PHY100H1:The Magic of Physics::24L/12T:This course provides a survey of Physics
column2: including both Classical and Modern Physics. It is designed for non-scientists
column3: and assumes no background in either science or mathematics. The approach to the course is broad rather than deep. We will concentrate on the concepts underlying such fascinating topics as planetary motion
column11: and climate change. We will uncover the wonders of the classical and the quantum worlds courtesy of Galileo
column15: Heisenberg and many others. ( PHY100H1 is primarily intended as a Breadth Requirement course for students in the Humanities and Social Sciences with no university-level background in physics. Any student with university-level credit in physics
column16: including students with secondary school transfer credits in physics is ineligible to take this course).::::Any PHY course taken previously or concurrently (except  PHY196H1/  PHY197H1/  PHY198H1/  PHY199H1/  PHY202H1/  PHY205H1/  PHY207H1):Science:

column1: PHY131H1:Introduction to Physics I::36L/20P:A first university physics course primarily for students not intending to pursue a Specialist or Major program in Physical or Mathematical Sciences. Topics include: classical kinematics & dynamics
column11: sound. Lab kit fees of $50 may apply.::MAT135H1/  MAT137Y1/  MAT157Y1 recommended:MCV4U Calculus & Vectors / MHF4U Functions & Calculus

column1: PHY132H1:Introduction to Physics II::36L/20P:The second university physics course primarily for students not intending to pursue a Specialist or Major program in Physical or Mathematical Sciences. Topics include: electricity
column5: special relativity. Lab kit fees of $50 may apply.:PHY131H1/ PHY151H1:MAT136H1/  MAT137Y1/  MAT157Y1 recommended::PHY152H1:Science:

column1: PHY151H1:Foundations of Physics I::36L/30P:The first physics course in many of the Specialist and Major Programs in Physical Sciences. It provides an introduction to the concepts
column2: approaches and tools the physicist uses to describe the physical world while laying the foundation for classical and modern mechanics. Topics include: mathematics of physics
column8: and special relativity.:MCV4U Calculus & Vectors / MCB4U Functions & Calculus; SPH4U Physics:MAT137Y1/ MAT157Y1::PHY131H1:Science:

column1: PHY152H1:Foundations of Physics II::36L/30P:The concept of fields will be introduced and discussed in the context of gravity and electricity. Topics include rotational motion
column4: electricity and magnetism.:PHY131H1/ PHY151H1/ PHY180H1:MAT137Y1/ MAT157Y1::PHY132H1:Science:

column1: PHY189H1:Introduction to Research Methods in the Physical and Mathematical Sciences::24P/24S:This course is an introduction to research challenges and methods in physical and mathematical sciences. Topics include documenting scientific work
column4: mathematical modelling and measurement of simple physical systems
column11: ethical and social issues in science
column12: and communicating scientific work orally and in writing.::MCV4U Calculus & Vectors; SPH4U Physics / SCH4U Chemistry / ICS4U Computer Science / SES4U Earth and Space Science:::Science:

column1: PHY196H1:Emergence in Nature::24S:The universe is not a rigid clockwork
column2: but neither is it formless and random. Instead
column3: it is filled with highly organized
column4: evolved structures that have somehow emerged from simple rules of physics. Examples range from the structure of galaxies to the pattern of ripples on windblown sand
column5: to biological and even social processes. These phenomena exist in spite of the universal tendency towards disorder. How is this possible? Self-organization challenges the usual reductionistic scientific method
column6: and begs the question of whether we can ever really understand or predict truly complex systems. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:No prior experience with physical science will be required
column7: but familiarity with Grade 10 mathematics will be assumed.::::Science:

column1: PHY197H1:Modern Physics for the Curious::24S:Have you wondered about the origin and workings of the natural world around us? Have you found physical science interesting but inaccessible because it was too full of math and jargon? Have you felt a pull to become more science-literate? If so
column2: this seminar course is for you -- or for anyone interested in understanding more about the universe
column4: seen through the lens of modern physics. Ideas on the menu will include: particle physics
column11: and big bang cosmology. The intriguing story of these integrated phenomena unfolds over a wide distance and a long time. Students from diverse academic backgrounds are warmly welcome. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:No prior experience with physical science will be required
column12: but familiarity with Grade 10 mathematics will be assumed.::::Science:

column1: PHY198H1:Physics at the Cutting Edge::24L/12S:A limited enrollment seminar course for First Year Science students interested in current research in Physics. Students will meet active researchers studying the universe from the centre of the earth to the edge of the cosmos. Topics may range from string theory to experimental biological physics
column2: from climate change to quantum computing
column3: from superconductivity to earthquakes. The course may involve both individual and group work
column4: essays and oral presentations. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:PHY151H1:PHY152H1

column1: PHY199H1:Dark Matter and Dark Energy are the New Black::24S:It is now 90 years since astronomers found the first evidence for a form of matter that wasn't part of the stars in our galaxies
column2: but rather is "dark" and has a gravitational attraction to ordinary matter. Other lines of evidence lead us to believe that there is six times more dark matter than the ordinary matter we are familiar with. Despite this
column4: direct evidence for what this dark matter might be. It is one of the biggest puzzles in particle physics and cosmology. In the last decade
column5: we have also discovered that something else is going on – the universe appears to be filled with "dark energy" that causes the expansion of our universe to speed up instead of slowdown. We will discuss what we know about the hypotheses of dark matter and dark energy
column6: and the debates about what might really be going on. Are we seeing science in crisis
column7: with a revolution just around the corner
column8: or is this just the "normal science" talked about by Kuhn and other philosophers of science? Participants will be expected to participate in seminar-style discussions
column9: as well as take the lead on at least one topic of discussion. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:No prior experience with physical science will be required
column10: but familiarity with Grade 10 mathematics will be assumed.::::Science:

column1: PHY202H1:The Physics of Science Fiction and Gaming::24L/12T:The physics of time travel
column6: and other physics related topics found in literature
column8: and gaming. The course will analyze the realism of physical phenomena in these media
column9: and consider the impact of these concepts on science and society. ( PHY202H1 is primarily intended as a Breadth Requirement course for students in the Humanities and Social Sciences with no university-level background in physics. Any student with university-level credit in physics
column10: including students with secondary school transfer credits in physics is ineligible to take this course).::::Any PHY course taken previously or concurrently (except  PHY196H1/  PHY197H1/  PHY198H1/  PHY199H1/  PHY100H1/  PHY205H1/  PHY207H1).:Science:

column1: PHY205H1:The Physics of Everyday Life::24L/12T:An introduction to the physics of everyday life. ( PHY205H1 is primarily intended as a Breadth Requirement course for students in the Humanities and Social Sciences with no university-level background in physics. Any student with university-level credit in physics
column2: including students with secondary school transfer credits in physics is ineligible to take this course).::::Any PHY course taken previously or concurrently (except  PHY196H1/  PHY197H1/  PHY198H1/  PHY199H1/  PHY100H1/  PHY202H1/  PHY207H1).:Science:

column1: PHY207H1:The Physics of Music::24L/12T:An online course intended to provide non-science students with a basic understanding of the science behind sound and music. Topics include oscillations

column1: PHY231H1:Physics of Living Systems::24L/18P:An introductory course for students interested in understanding the physical phenomena occurring in biological systems and the applications of physics in life sciences. Topics may include physical processes inside living cells and systems
PHY250H1:Electricity and Magnetism::24L/12T:An introductory course in Electromagnetism. Topics include: Point charges

column1: PHY252H1:Thermal Physics::24L/12T:The quantum statistical basis of macroscopic systems; definition of entropy in terms of the number of accessible states of a many particle system leading to simple expressions for absolute temperature
column3: and the laws of thermodynamics. Specific effects of quantum statistics at high densities and low temperatures.:PHY132H1/ PHY152H1

column1: PHY254H1:Classical Mechanics::24L/12T:The course analyzes the linear
column2: nonlinear and chaotic behaviour of classical mechanical systems such as harmonic oscillators
column4: and central field systems. The course will develop the analytical and numerical tools to solve such systems and determine their basic properties. The course will include mathematical analysis
column6: and participatory demonstrations of mechanical systems.:PHY132H1/ PHY152H1 ( PHY152H1 recommended)
column8: MAT136H1)/ MAT137Y1/ MAT157Y1:MAT235Y1/ MAT237Y1/ MAT257Y1:MAT244H1/ MAT267H1

column1: PHY256H1:Introduction to Quantum Physics::24L/12T:Failures of classical physics; the Quantum revolution; Stern-Gerlach effect; harmonic oscillator; uncertainty principle; interference packets; scattering and tunneling in one-dimension.:PHY132H1/ PHY152H1

PHY356H1:Quantum Mechanics I::24L/12T:The general structure of wave mechanics; eigenfunctions and eigenvalues; operators; orbital angular momentum; spherical harmonics; central potential; separation of variables; hydrogen atom; Dirac notation; operator methods; harmonic oscillator and spin.:MAT223H1/  MAT240H1
PHY357H1:Nuclear and Particle Physics::24L/12T:The subatomic particles; nuclei
column4: leptons and bosons; the structure of nuclei and hadronic matter; symmetries and conservation laws; fundamental forces and interactions
column7: and strong; a selection of other topics: CP violation
column12: nuclear and particle astrophysics. This course is not a prerequisite for any PHY400-level course.:PHY356H1::::Science:

column1: PHY358H1:Quantum Materials: from Atoms to Crystals::24L/12T:This course covers the most important iconic quantum systems
column2: from the hydrogen atom through to solid state systems
column3: focusing on how quantum mechanics is applied and determines physical properties of atoms
column5: and crystals. It begins with the hydrogen atom
column6: including orbital and spin angular momentum
column8: and effects of the magnetic field
column9: and then extends to systems of two identical particles: bosons vs. fermions and the helium atom with two electrons. Other topics include spin singlets and triplets
column12: the effects of electron-electron interactions and diatomic molecules. For crystals

PHY392H1:Physics of Climate::24L:This course provides an introduction to climate physics and the earth-atmosphere-ocean system. Topics include solar and terrestrial radiation; global energy balance; radiation laws; radiative transfer; atmospheric structure; convection; the meridional structure of the atmosphere; the general circulation of the atmosphere; the ocean and its circulation; and climate variability.:PHY250H1/ PHY252H1

PHY405H1:Electronics Lab::12L/36P:Electrical circuits
column2: networks and devices are all-pervasive in the modern world. This laboratory course is an introduction to the world of electronics. Students will learn the joys and perils of electronics
column4: constructing and debugging circuits and devices. The course will cover topics ranging from filters and operational amplifiers to micro-controllers
column5: and will introduce students to concepts such as impedance
column8: PHY250H1. Note that  PHY405H1 may be taken in third or fourth year.::::Science:

column1: PHY407H1:Computational Physics::12L/36P:This is an introduction to scientific computing in physics. Students will be introduced to computational techniques used in a range of physics research areas. By considering select physics topics
column2: students will learn basic computational methods for function analysis (computing integrals and derivatives; finding roots and extrema)
column3: resolution of linear and non-linear equations
column7: PDEs and Monte Carlo techniques. As the course progresses
column8: students will develop their skills at debugging
column10: computational efficiency and accuracy. The course is based on python and will involve working on a set of computational labs throughout the semester as well as a final project.:PHY224H1/ PHY254H1:Any third or fourth year course in Physics:::Science:

column1: PHY408H1:Time Series Analysis::12L/24P:The analysis of digital sequences; filters; the Fourier Transform; windows; truncation effects; aliasing; auto and cross-correlation; stochastic processes
column2: power spectra; least squares filtering; application to real data series and experimental design.:PHY407H1/ PHY224H1/ PHY250H1/ PHY254H1/ PHY324H1.  PHY408H1 may be taken in third or fourth year:Any third or fourth year lecture course in Physics:::Science:

column1: PHY424H1:Advanced Physics Laboratory::72P:Experiments in this course are designed to form a bridge to current experimental research. A wide range of exciting experiments relevant to modern research in physics is available. The laboratory is normally open from 9 a.m. - 4 p.m.

Models based on physical principles applied to cellular processes will be developed. Biological computational modeling will be introduced.:PHY250H1
PHY450H1:Relativistic Electrodynamics::24L/12T:An introduction to relativistic electrodynamics. Topics include: special relativity
column3: relativistic dynamics from the Principle of Stationary Action and Maxwell's equations in Lorentz covariant form. Noether's theorem for fields and the energy-momentum tensor. Fields of moving charges and electromagnetic radiation: retarded potential

column1: PHY452H1:Statistical Mechanics::24L/12T:Classical and quantum statistical mechanics of noninteracting systems; the statistical basis of thermodynamics; ensembles
column2: partition function; thermodynamic equilibrium; stability and fluctuations; formulation of quantum statistics; theory of simple gases; ideal Bose and Fermi systems.:PHY252H1

column1: PHY454H1:Continuum Mechanics::24L/12T:The theory of continuous matter
column2: including solid and fluid mechanics. Topics include the continuum approximation

PHY460H1:Nonlinear Physics::24L/12T:The theory of nonlinear dynamical systems with applications to many areas of physics. Topics include stability
column7: analytical and computational methods will be developed.:PHY354H1::::Science:

column1: POL196H1:First-Year Foundation Seminar: The China Challenge::24S:China’s meteoric rise to great power status has triggered an intense international debate over its global implications. While many analysts see Beijing’s rise as posing a threat to global political and economic stability
column2: Chinese leaders have argued forcefully that China’s efforts to regain its historic preeminence will result in a ‘win-win” outcome for all states. This course will assess the merits of these contending positions through an historical examination of China’s 20th century renaissance. The course will begin by tracing the long period of imperial decline in the 19th century
column3: culminating in China’s revolutionary rebirth as a Marxist state in 1949. A major focus will be on the Mao-era legacy of revolutionary diplomacy and the foreign policy consequences of its later transformation into a market-authoritarian powerhouse. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: POL197H1:First-Year Foundation Seminar: Politics and Sports: Identity

column1: POL387H1:Politics in Europe::24L:This course applies the basic concepts in comparative politics to the political systems of Europe. We will cover theories of transitions to democracy
column2: formation and development of the nation-state
column4: parties and party systems and elections and electoral behaviour. We will use these theories to gain a better understanding of politics in Europe. We will also address some of the major challenges that Europe and the EU have recently faced such as the eurozone crisis
column6: the rise of populism and extreme right parties and the challenges of immigration and incorporation of minorities. The goal is for students to become familiar with the politics and governments of contemporary Europe through the lens of current and classic themes in comparative politics.:1.0 credit in POL/ JPA/ JPF/ JPI/ JPR/ JPS/ JRA courses

POL405H1:The Military Instrument of Foreign Policy: Concepts and Approaches::24S:In light of endemic international threats and conflicts

column5: arms control and war termination strategies.:POL208H1/ POL208Y1/ POL209H5/ POLB80H3:::POL459Y1:Social Science:

POL412H1:Human Rights and International Relations::24S:Human rights have become dominant in international politics since the end of World War II. The process of creating and implementing human rights is political. We explore historical
column3: and empirical explanations of the roots
column5: and implications of human rights today through a variety of topics.:POL201H1/ POL201Y1/ POL208H1/ POL208Y1/ POL209H5/ POLB80H3/ POLB90H3/ POLB91H3::::Social Science:

column1: POL413H1:Global Environmental Politics::24S:Examines the challenges faced by humanity in dealing with global environmental problems and the politics of addressing them. Focuses on both the underlying factors that shape the politics of global environmental problems such as scientific uncertainty
column3: and globalization and explores attempts at the governance of specific environmental issues.:POL208H1/ POL208Y1/ POL209H5/ POLB80H3:::POLD89H3:Social Science:

column1: POL416H1:Civil War and Counterinsurgency::24S:This course overviews the origins
column3: and outcomes of civil war and counterinsurgency. It provides a theoretical
column5: and methodological foundation for understanding these forms of conflict
column7: and the determinants of their duration and outcomes.:POL208H1/ POL208Y1/ POL209H5/ POL210H5/ POLB80H3::Familiarity with quantitative methods is strongly recommended (example:  POL222H1

column1: POL417H1:Politics of North-South Relations::24S:This course explores the complex relations between the developed world and Global South in historical and contemporary settings. It engages critical scholarship within International Politics and International Political Economy to examine salient factors in North-South relations such as dependency and interdependence
column5: and South-South cooperation.:POL201H1/ POL201Y1/ POL208H1/ POL208Y1/ POL209H5/ POLB80H3/ POLB90H3:::POL417Y1:Social Science:

column1: POL418H1:Human Security and Intra-state Conflicts in the Global South::24S:What are the underlying causes of insecurity and instability
column2: and what factors support or undermine attainment of durable peace after episodes of violent conflict in the Global South? This course explores these questions by focusing on identity-based conflicts and through comparative case studies and theoretical perspectives from political science and related disciplines.:POL201H1/  POL201Y1/  POL208H1/  POL208Y1/  POL209H5/  POLB80H3/  POLB90H3:::POL417Y1:Social Science:

column1: POL419H1:Quantitative Methods and Data Analysis::24S:Covers advanced level treatment of quantitative empirical research methods in political science. The emphasis is given to theoretical foundations
column3: and statistical methods of “causal inference.” Students will also be exposed to prominent applications of these methods and learn how to use statistical software to apply these methods in data analysis.:POL232H1/0.5 credit in STA at the 200+ level::::Social Science:

column1: POL421H1:Maimonides and His Modern Interpreters::24S:The course offers an introduction to the seminal work of Jewish philosophy
column2: 'The Guide of the Perplexed' by Moses Maimonides. We will delve into some of the basic themes of Jewish philosophical theology and religion as they are treated by Maimonides.:POL200Y1/ POL200Y5/( POLC70H3

column1: POL426H1:Democracy and Dictatorship::24S:The course provides an in-depth introduction to theories of the origins of democracy and dictatorship. In the first part of the course
column2: we examine and compare theories rooted in economic development
column5: and historical institutionalism. The latter half of the course applies these different approaches to debates over the origins of Nazi rule in Germany in the 1930s
column6: military dictatorship in Chile in the 1970s
column7: and non-democratic rule in contemporary Russia.:2.0 credits in POL/ JPA/ JPF/ JPI/ JPR/ JPS/ JRA courses::::Social Science:

column1: POL428H1:Federalism and Diversity in Canada (and Beyond)::24S:Canada as a key case in comparative federalism studies
column2: with a particular focus on the management of diversity and conflict. Federal theory is applied to analyze federal institutions and dynamics in Canada (and other cases). Topics include the distribution of power
column3: the judiciary’s role and group representation.:POL214H1

column1: POL431H1:Dynamics of Political Change in Contemporary China::24S:This course will explore processes of political change in post-Mao China through an examination of selected systemic challenges and regime responses. The primary focus will be on processes of institutional development and decay as the Party-State regime evolves from hard to soft authoritarianism.::::POL431Y1:Social Science:

POL432H1:Feminist Political Thought::24S:Feminist theory offers basic challenges to the foundations of modern political and legal thought. It suggests a different conception of human nature and a different model of epistemology and of appropriate forms of argument about the traditional issues of legal and political theory: justice
column3: equality and freedom. Introduction to the foundations of feminist theory
column4: an analysis of its implications for traditional liberal theory
column5: and an application of feminist theory to law.:POL200Y1/  POL200Y5/ ( POLC70H3

column6: and transnational private governance.:2.0 credits in POL/ JPA/ JPF/ JPI/ JPR/ JPS/ JRA courses::::Social Science:

POL439H1:The Canadian Welfare State in Comparative Perspective::24S:The course examines contemporary Canadian social policy in light of the scholarly literature on the welfare states of advanced industrial societies. Topics include the variety of welfare state regimes in rich nations
column2: and their comparative performance in reducing inequality and poverty
column3: in labour market and economic outcomes
column4: and in addressing the specific circumstances of women. Specific Canadian policy fields examined will include pensions
column6: child care and health insurance.:POL214H1/ POL214Y1/ POL215H5/ POL216H5/ POL224H1/ POL224Y1/ POLB50Y3::::Social Science:

POL442H1:Topics in Latin American Politics::24S:The seminar focuses on five countries in the Andean region of Latin America: Venezuela
column4: Peru and Bolivia. First part deals with the challenges to democracy in the region. Second part explores potential solutions - in particular the drafting of new constitutions by popularly elected constituent assemblies.:( POL201H1/ POL201Y1/ POLB90H3/ POLB91H3)

POL444H1:Land and Indigenous Politics::24S:This seminar examines Indigenous politics through land. We explore transnational Indigenous politics by focusing on global struggles over land. The course considers how Indigenous land-based movements

column1: POL445H1:Politics of Growth in Developing Countries::24S:The course examines the politics of economic growth in developing countries. It focuses on political factors to analyze why some developing countries have done better in terms of growth than others. Conceptual frameworks of growth and related themes such as regime type

column3: and performance of the dominant neoliberal approach to development and poverty reduction. It also assesses the feasibility and efficacy of alternative development strategies. Case studies are drawn from Latin America
column5: and Africa.:POL201H1/ POL201Y1/ POL218H1/ POL301H1/ POL301Y1/ POL305H1/ POL305Y1/ POL309H1/ POL325H1/ POLB90H3/ POLB91H3::Introductory economics is helpful::Social Science:

column1: POL454H1:Innovation and Knowledge Transfer in City Regions::24S:This course surveys two of the key themes related to the process of innovation in a knowledge-based economy: the process by which new knowledge is generated and effectively transferred to those organizations with the potential to commercialize it; and secondly
column2: the paradoxical relationship between knowledge creation and proximity in a modern global economy. It examines the motivations and policy formulations of key states. The case studies focus on power projection
column4: and war termination strategies.:POL208H1/ POL208Y1/ POL209H5/ POLB80H3:::POL459Y1:Social Science:

column1: POL463H1:State and Society in 20th Century China::24S:This course will explore the sustainability of China's hybrid market-authoritarian system
column2: focusing on the challenges posed by the emergence of an assertive civil society and the impact of globalization on a complex and interdependent economy and society. Among the topics to be analyzed will be the role of public opinion
column3: social media and new forms of social and political control.::::POL431Y1:Social Science:

column1: POL467H1:The Politics of Immigration and Multiculturalism in Canada::24S:This course examines Canadian immigration and multiculturalism from theoretical
column2: empirical and applied perspectives. It includes a discussion of normative foundations
column3: an analysis of the components of the policy framework
column4: and an assessment of the impact of immigration and multiculturalism on other aspects of social
column5: cultural and political life.:POL214H1/ POL214Y1/ POL215H5/ POL216H5/ POL224H1/ POL224Y1/ POLB50Y3::::Social Science:

column1: POL469H1:Ethics and International Relations::24S:The course aims to explore the requirements of justice and fairness in international affairs. It is common to theorize international relations in terms of interests and power. But even the most cursory look at what important actors actually do in their international interactions reveals that they use normative language all the time. This has not gone unnoticed
column2: with investigations of ethics in the international arena multiplying in recent years. Drawing on readings from political philosophy
column5: the course will take up practical ethical dilemmas encountered in world affairs. The main focus of the course will be on institutions. Examples will be drawn from the issue areas of trade
column8: among others.:POL200Y1/ POL200Y5/ POL208H1/ POL208Y1/ POL209H5/ POLB80H3/( POLC70H3

column1: POL470H1:Media & Politics::24S:Technological change transformed the way politics is reported by journalists. This course introduces students to debates at the intersection of media and politics in Western democracies. Topics include the changing information environment
column5: and the rise of social and partisan media
column6: and misinformation.:2.0 credits in POL/ JPA/ JPF/ JPI/ JPR/ JPS/ JRA courses

column1: POL474H1:Politics and Policy Analysis::24S:Major theories of public policy-making and related approaches to policy analysis are examined from the perspective of political science. Key contributions to the theoretical literature pertaining to leading models are read and discussed. Models of public policy-making are successively applied to analysis of cases of Canadian and comparative policy development.:POL214H1/ POL214Y1/ POL215H5/ POL216H5/ POL224H1/ POL224Y1/ POLB50Y3::::Social Science:
POL475H1:Postmodern and Contemporary Thought::24S:Study of postmodern and contemporary themes. Beginning with political economy
column2: then the effect of technology on politics
column3: a discussion of Western colonialism leading to a revised concept of social relations. Social contract theory will be analyzed through a natural contract as well as examination of individualism and the posthuman.:::POL200Y1 and  POL320Y1:POL475Y1:Social Science:

column1: POL479H1:Topics in Middle East Politics::24S:The course examines the contemporary politics of the Middle East and North Africa. It seeks to examine the relative importance of political
column2: socio-economic and ideological factors in the context of such issues as the resilience of authoritarianism
column4: and the resurgence of Islamic activism. Theoretical discussion is followed by case studies.:POL201H1/ POL201Y1/ POLB90H3/ POLB91H3::::Social Science:

column1: POL480H1:Studies in Comparative Political Theory::24S:We will critically examine what “comparative political theory” is and what it would mean to genuinely “deparochialize” political theory
column3: to de-center Euro-American thought in the study of political ideas. The course neither presupposes background knowledge of any non-Western thought tradition
column4: nor does it aspire to provide students with sufficient knowledge of particular traditions to ground serious scholarly contributions to this emerging field. To provide that background would require a series of specialized courses in
column12: the course aims at sharpening our understanding of (a) the purposes served by “deparochializing” political theory; and (b) the various methods by which we can seek to serve these purposes.:POL200Y1/ POL200Y5/( POLC70H3

column1: PSY194H1:The Psychology of Student Success::24S:University life presents students with all sorts of challenges as well as amazing opportunities for learning and growth. While there are many different ways to define a “successful student”
column2: the goal of this seminar is for everyone to develop the knowledge
column4: and mindset needed to make the most of out of the university experience. Students will discover what research in psychological science has to say about facing and overcoming common academic
column7: as we cover topics including deliberate practice
column9: and belongingness. Students will also learn evidence-based strategies for better managing their attention
column11: and emotions so that they may thrive (rather than just survive) in university. In addition to learning about psychology
column12: students will develop useful skills in scientific literacy
column16: and teamwork. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Science:

column1: PSY195H1:The Science of Babies and Children::24S:This course will use an interdisciplinary perspective to explore how the infant mind emerges and grows. Topics could include how brain plasticity influences “critical” or “sensitive” periods for learning
column3: cognition and behaviour can offer us critical insights into long-standing philosophical questions. Note that specific content will depend on the instructor and will be posted on the Department of Psychology’s Undergraduate Course Information webpage. During the course
column4: students will (1) engage in lively discussion and present their perspectives; (2) use exploratory writing to develop arguments and their understanding of subject matter; and (3) begin to read and summarize scientific research papers in Developmental Psychology. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Science:

column1: PSY197H1:Rethinking the Human Mind::24S:This course will use an interdisciplinary perspective to explore the quirks
column3: and puzzles of the human mind. Topics could include how technology and tools extend our minds
column4: or the light that our ability (and inability) to reason sheds on human nature. Note that specific content will depend on the instructor and will be posted on the Department of Psychology’s Undergraduate Course Information webpage. During the course
column5: students will: (1) engage in lively discussion and present their perspectives; and (2) use exploratory writing to develop arguments and their understanding of the subject matter. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Science:

column1: PSY198H1:The Psychology of Magic::24S:Magicians entertain us with their tricks. What appears as “Magic” is based on fundamental aspects of human psychology: visual and auditory perception
column5: and verbal abilities. In this class
column6: we will consider and discuss the psychological basis of magic tricks and use magic to explore aspects of psychology. The class will require reading of scientific articles and book chapters as well as watching and analyzing magical tricks. The only prerequisite is a curious and critical mind. The course puts great emphasis on writing and on starting to read primary scientific literature. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Science:

column1: PSY199H1:Psychology and History of Drug Use::24S:This seminar will examine the historical and contemporary use of drugs. Students will be introduced to the general psychological and neuroscientific mechanisms by which drugs affect human behavior
column2: and explore highlights of current research on drug effects in animals and humans. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Science:

column1: PSY203H1:Psychological Research::36P:This course provides an introduction to conceiving
column3: and conducting research in psychology. It prepares students to be both consumers and producers of scientific research
column4: and also addresses basic issues related to the work of psychological scientists such as theory development
column6: and scientific writing. Students in this course will gain insight into the scientific process as a whole – its advantages
column9: students will be able to better evaluate the knowledge that psychological science can provide
column10: and integrate that knowledge into a broader worldview.:PSY100H1/  PSY100Y5/ ( PSYA01H3

column1: PSY204H1:Psychology Careers and Applications::36L:Psychology has been identified as a hub science
column2: a discipline whose research influences the work of scientists in many other fields. This course will provide students with a broad introduction to the application of the psychological sciences across various clinical
column4: and industry contexts. Students will gain valuable insight into the broad range of careers that are relevant to psychology
column5: while also investigating barriers to rigorous application of psychological science in applied settings. Students will also learn how the skills and knowledge gained in an undergraduate psychology program can be applied to a broad range of careers and fields/sectors. Students will gain significant exposure to career and education planning considerations within the psychological sciences and will participate in at least one experiential career exploration activity.:PSY100H1/  PSY100Y5/ ( PSYA01H3 +  PSYA02H3)::0.5 PSY credit at the 200-level::Science:

column1: PSY321H1:Cross-Cultural Psychology::36L:One of the hallmarks of human behaviour is its diversity. Some of the ways in which we differ are thought to be relatively idiosyncratic (e.g.
column3: whereas others are fairly systematic. Cultural psychology is one area of research in human behaviour that examines systematic differences resulting from individuals’ cultural backgrounds. column1: PSY324H1:Moral Thought and Behaviour::36L:Moral values vary considerably across individuals
column4: and cultures. What explains the emergence of these differential moral systems? What psychological processes are involved in moral decisions and actions? How might insights from psychological research shed light on contemporary
column5: ‘hot-button’ moral issues? How are moral decisions similar to – and different from – other types of everyday decisions? What is the role of emotion in moral decision making? As an introduction to the field of moral psychology
column6: this 300-level course will cover research from a range of sub-disciplines within psychology including social-personality psychology
column9: students will gain exposure to related material in other fields including philosophy
column11: and economics. Students will gain a firm understanding of the key debates and issues in the study of the moral mind and will gain skills in critical thinking and writing.:PSY201H1/  ECO220Y1/  EEB225H1/  GGR270H1/  IRW220H1/  POL222H1/  SOC202H1/  STA220H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA288H1/  PSY201H5/  STA215H5/  STA220H5/  PSYB07H3/  STAB22H3/  STAB23H3/  STAB57H3

column1: PSY360H1:Associative Learning::36L:Learning allows our experiences to shape what we know
column2: what we can do and how we interact with our environments. This course addresses the fundamental concepts and more important research findings related to contemporary theories of associative learning in animals and humans. It examines the application of such fundamental research to issues such as the neural substrates of behaviour
column4: and anxiety disorders. It is designed to foster skills in critical thinking

column1: PSY402H1:Psychology Seminar::24S:Undergraduate students who are given permission to take a seminar at the graduate level offered through the Dept. of Psychology’s Graduate Program will be enrolled into this course code. Permission to take a graduate seminar for undergraduate credit must be obtained through three channels. First
column2: the instructor of the grad course must give the student permission. It is ultimately up to instructor to decide whether the course is appropriate for undergraduate students
column3: as well as if the specific student has the appropriate academic background to succeed in the course. Accordingly
column4: the student may be asked to provide details about their relevant academic and/or research experience to assess their qualifications. Second
column5: the Graduate Administrator (psy.graduate@utoronto.ca) must confirm if there is space in the course after graduate students have enrolled. Finally
column6: the Undergraduate Administrator (psy.undergrad@utoronto.ca) must receive an email from the Graduate Administrator confirming that the student has permission to enrol. The following information must be included in the email: Student name
column8: graduate course code and term (F or S)
column9: and the course subtitle. The student will then be enrolled into this undergraduate course code by the Department. It is the student’s responsibility to contact the graduate instructor to initiate this process and to follow-up with both the Graduate and Undergraduate Administrators to ensure their enrolment.:::::Science:

column1: PSY405H1:Individual Projects:::A single semester intensive laboratory or applied research project for students who seek hands-on research experience to complement our regular course offerings. Each project culminates in a scholarly paper and oral presentation. Students must secure a faculty supervisor from the Dept. of Psychology and submit a completed application form that includes details about the project before the start of the semester. Application forms are available on the Department’s website (https://psych.utoronto.ca/programs-and-courses/undergraduate-course-information) and must be emailed to the undergraduate office (psy.undergrad@utoronto.ca) by the end of the first week of September for fall projects
column2: the start of the second week in January for winter projects. If you’re registering for a summer project
column3: please submit it by the beginning of the first week in May. This course is open to all students.:PSY202H1/  ECO220Y1/  SOC252H1/  STA221H1/  PSY202H5/  STA221H5/  PSYC08H3/  STAB27H3/  STAC32H3
column4: and the appropriate background in Psychology for the proposed work (e.g.
column5: PSY210H1 if the project is in the area of Developmental Psychology)::::Science:

column1: PSY422H1:Community Psychology & Advocacy::24L:This course is designed for students who are eager to apply their knowledge of psychological science to social problems. Students will be introduced to the fundamentals of community psychology while also examining how social psychological theory and research can be applied to understand and address issues that affect communities. This course will help students develop the skills and confidence necessary to advocate successfully on public interest issues relevant to psychology. Students will also work in partners/teams with a community advocacy group to collaboratively address a specific problem or need of the organization. Through a guided process of practice and reflection
column2: students will increase their self-efficacy and come to recognize their ability to use their psychological knowledge and skills to make change in the world. Classroom discussions will integrate community experiences with lecture material. Enrolment is by application (see psychology department website or contact the department for more information at psy.undergrad@utoronto.ca). Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:PSY202H1/  ECO220Y1/  SOC252H1/  STA221H1/  PSY202H5/  STA221H5/  PSYC08H3/  STAB27H3/  STAC32H3

column1: PSY424H1:Social Psychology of Interpersonal Relationships::36L:This lecture course focuses on the social psychology of interpersonal relationships between individuals
column2: especially romantic or close relationships and friendships. It surveys what social psychologists have learned about the development
column4: disruption or dissolution of personal relationships
column5: as well as current social psychological theories of interpersonal relationships.:PSY201H1/  ECO220Y1/  EEB225H1/  GGR270H1/  IRW220H1/  POL222H1/  SOC202H1/  STA220H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA288H1/  PSY201H5/  STA215H5/  STA220H5/  PSYB07H3/  STAB22H3/  STAB23H3/  STAB57H3

column1: PSY425H1:Self and Identity::36L:The distinguishing feature of human consciousness is self-consciousness -- our ability to be aware of and interpret ourselves and our experiences. All our higher capabilities as a species rest upon this foundation. Self-consciousness allows us to develop an understanding of who we are as individuals and in relation to others. This lecture course brings together ideas and perspectives from across the social sciences to explore the nature of self-consciousness. The institutional relations and cultural practices that give shape to contemporary forms of identity and self-experience are also examined.:PSY201H1/  ECO220Y1/  EEB225H1/  GGR270H1/  IRW220H1/  POL222H1/  SOC202H1/  STA220H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA288H1/  PSY201H5/  STA215H5/  STA220H5/  PSYB07H3/  STAB22H3/  STAB23H3/  STAB57H3
PSY426H1:Motivational Theories in Social Psychology::36L:With intensive reading and discussion of ‘classic’ and contemporary articles
column2: this advanced lecture course in social psychology focuses on the central issues
column4: and findings in the study of motivation. Topics include self-regulation
column6: and reward/punishment.:PSY201H1/  ECO220Y1/  EEB225H1/  GGR270H1/  IRW220H1/  POL222H1/  SOC202H1/  STA220H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA288H1/  PSY201H5/  STA215H5/  STA220H5/  PSYB07H3/  STAB22H3/  STAB23H3/  STAB57H3

column1: PSY427H1:Media Psychology::36L:This course in critical media literacy examines how we come to understand ourselves and our world
column5: through the simulative mediation of information and communication technologies. The aim is to provide students with a deeper understanding of the dynamic symbolic environment that surrounds them and in which they participate as both audience and producer. The approach is multidisciplinary
column6: drawing not only from psychology but a broad range of influential perspectives in the social sciences and humanities. The topics explored reveal how developments in the world of media are central to understanding changing forms of public and private life in the 21st century.:PSY201H1/  ECO220Y1/  EEB225H1/  GGR270H1/  IRW220H1/  POL222H1/  SOC202H1/  STA220H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA288H1/  PSY201H5/  STA215H5/  STA220H5/  PSYB07H3/  STAB22H3/  STAB23H3/  STAB57H3

column1: PSY428H1:Critical Psychology::36L:This course examines the place of psychology in broader society and culture. What are the consequences of our research and professional practices for how we understand and govern ourselves and others? What is the basis and extent of our authority and power to describe
column3: and explain human behaviour and experience? How do our values direct our activities and interpretations as psychologists? How can we critically evaluate the assumptions
column5: and achievements of our discipline in relation to real or imagined alternatives?:PSY201H1/  ECO220Y1/  EEB225H1/  GGR270H1/  IRW220H1/  POL222H1/  SOC202H1/  STA220H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA288H1/  PSY201H5/  STA215H5/  STA220H5/  PSYB07H3/  STAB22H3/  STAB23H3/  STAB57H3

column1: PSY435H1:Environmental Psychology::36L:This lecture course explores how psychologists can contribute to finding solutions to today's pressing environmental challenges. Topics include persuasion
column5: and the many ways in which the physical environment affects psychological processes. The course takes a multi-scalar approach to the human-environment relationship
column8: cultural and global levels of scale
column9: through the lens of complex dynamic systems theories.:PSY100H1/  PSY100Y5/ ( PSYA01H3

column3: and shifts in areas of theory and research
column4: as well as history and philosophy of science
column5: in general.:1.0 PSY credit at the 200-level:::PSYC85H3:Science:

column1: PSY455H1:Psychological Research Now and Then::36L:This course delves into some of the most influential experiments across psychology subfields by discussing how they were conceived
column3: and conducted. Students will learn how these classic findings shaped theory
column4: how to reinterpret them with the benefit of the current knowledge in the field
column5: as well as how and if their experimental designs can be modified to meet current scientific standards and address still open questions. Students will leave this course equipped to be both critical consumers and producers of scientific research. This course will combine lectures with student presentations.:( PSY202H1/  ECO220Y1/  SOC252H1/  STA221H1/  PSY202H5/  STA221H5/  PSYC08H3/  STAB27H3/  STAC32H3) and ( PSY203H1/  PSYB70H3)::::Science:

column1: PSY473H1:Social Cognitive Neuroscience::36L:Social cognitive neuroscience is an emerging interdisciplinary field that seeks to integrate theories of social psychology and cognitive neuroscience to understand behaviour at three fundamentally interrelated levels of analysis (social
column3: and neural). Topics such as self-regulation
column8: and prejudice will be examined in this lecture course.:PSY201H1/  ECO220Y1/  EEB225H1/  GGR270H1/  IRW220H1/  POL222H1/  SOC202H1/  STA220H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA288H1/  PSY201H5/  STA215H5/  STA220H5/  PSYB07H3/  STAB22H3/  STAB23H3/  STAB57H3

column1: PSY474H1:Computation in Psychology::36L:This lecture course surveys computational perspectives on the mind and brain and introduces computational tools for connecting psychological and neural data to theory. Topics may include neural networks
column4: and other techniques applicable to psychological research and general analysis. Basic familiarity with programming is recommended but not required.:PSY202H1/ ECO220Y1/ SOC252H1/ STA221H1/ PSY202H5/ STA221H5/ PSYC08H3/ STAB27H3/ STAC32H3::::Science:

column1: PSY475H1:Attention and Performance::36L:This lecture course discusses a range of topics in visual cognition and human performance. Topics covered may include attention
column4: the processing of features and objects
column5: and cognitive motor control in eye and limb movements.:PSY201H1/  ECO220Y1/  EEB225H1/  GGR270H1/  IRW220H1/  POL222H1/  SOC202H1/  STA220H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA288H1/  PSY201H5/  STA215H5/  STA220H5/  PSYB07H3/  STAB22H3/  STAB23H3/  STAB57H3

Course capacity is limited to 20 students and enrolment priority is given to PSY Specialists and Research Specialists.:PSY202H1/ ECO220Y1/ SOC252H1/ STA221H1/ PSY202H5/ STA221H5/ PSYC08H3/ STAB27H3/ STAC32H3

column5: and higher cortical systems.). Content in any given year depends on instructor. Course capacity is limited to 20 students and enrolment priority is given to PSY Specialists and Research Specialists.:PSY202H1/ ECO220Y1/ SOC252H1/ STA221H1/ PSY202H5/ STA221H5/ PSYC08H3/ STAB27H3/ STAC32H3

column1: PSY492H1:Neurobiology of Learning and Memory::36L:Understanding the complexities of how the mammalian nervous system acquires and stores information and how it transforms this information into appropriate behavior is fundamentally important to our understanding of both animal and human behavior. This lecture course explores empirical and theoretical contributions to our understanding of the neural basis of learning and memory.:PSY201H1/  ECO220Y1/  EEB225H1/  GGR270H1/  IRW220H1/  POL222H1/  SOC202H1/  STA220H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA288H1/  PSY201H5/  STA215H5/  STA220H5/  PSYB07H3/  STAB22H3/  STAB23H3/  STAB57H3

column1: PSY493H1:Cognitive Neuroscience::36L:This is a capstone lecture course surveying research on how the mind arises from the brain. The first objective of the course is to understand how processes in human brains (ranging from the firing of a single neuron to the dynamics of billions) support cognitive abilities (such as recognizing a face
column3: understanding the words in a spoken lecture
column4: or planning a route home from class). The second objective of the course is to understand the methods of contemporary cognitive neuroscience research
column5: to enable students to read primary literature and to understand ongoing debates.:PSY201H1/  ECO220Y1/  EEB225H1/  GGR270H1/  IRW220H1/  POL222H1/  SOC202H1/  STA220H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA288H1/  PSY201H5/  STA215H5/  STA220H5/  PSYB07H3/  STAB22H3/  STAB23H3/  STAB57H3

column1: PSY494H1:Physiology and Psychology of Emotion::36L:This lecture course discusses the role of brain and body in the expression and experience of emotion in humans considered through the experimental
column4: and clinical literatures.:PSY201H1/  ECO220Y1/  EEB225H1/  GGR270H1/  IRW220H1/  POL222H1/  SOC202H1/  STA220H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA288H1/  PSY201H5/  STA215H5/  STA220H5/  PSYB07H3/  STAB22H3/  STAB23H3/  STAB57H3

column1: PSY495H1:Sex and the Brain::36L:This lecture course explores the scientific literature underlying the concept that female/male
column3: and transgendered behaviours are based on brain differences. Original scientific papers will be read in close detail for design and interpretation of the experiments. The goal is to gain an understanding of the science and psychology underlying sex/gender
column5: and the sexual brain. Topics include: the making of sex
column9: and sex and sexuality/gender identification.:PSY201H1/  ECO220Y1/  EEB225H1/  GGR270H1/  IRW220H1/  POL222H1/  SOC202H1/  STA220H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA288H1/  PSY201H5/  STA215H5/  STA220H5/  PSYB07H3/  STAB22H3/  STAB23H3/  STAB57H3

column1: PSY496H1:Cognitive Dysfunction in Neurological Disorders::36L:This lecture course provides an in-depth examination of the cognitive dysfunction found in neurological disorders
column4: and Schizophrenia. The course focuses on how cognitive impairments relate to neuropsychological models of the specific disease (specifically how these models provide insights into the biological mechanisms underlying the cognitive symptoms) and cognition
column5: more broadly.:PSY201H1/  ECO220Y1/  EEB225H1/  GGR270H1/  IRW220H1/  POL222H1/  SOC202H1/  STA220H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA288H1/  PSY201H5/  STA215H5/  STA220H5/  PSYB07H3/  STAB22H3/  STAB23H3/  STAB57H3

column1: PSY497H1:Seminar in Biological Timing::24S:This is an advanced seminar course that examines the mechanisms and significance of timing and timekeeping at several levels of organization in living organisms. Topics include the roles of clocks and oscillations in physiology and behaviour
column2: and the importance of timing in sensorimotor integration
column5: and health. Course capacity is limited to 20 students and enrolment priority is given to PSY Specialists and Research Specialists.:PSY202H1/ ECO220Y1/ SOC252H1/ STA221H1/ PSY202H5/ STA221H5/ PSYC08H3/ STAB27H3/ STAC32H3

column1: REN241H1:Renaissance Masterworks and Remixes::24S:Focusing on one or more iconic works in literature
column4: this course explores the most celebrated cultural productions of the Renaissance and their subsequent adaptations and appropriations in later and modern popular culture.::::VIC241H1

column1: REN242H1:Scientific Worldviews of the Renaissance::24L:An in-depth study of late medieval and early modern scientific worldviews
column2: with a focus on interconnections between natural philosophy
column9: and ethics. Through a consideration of early modern ideas including free will and determinism
column14: this course investigates some of the period’s key metaphysical and methodological assumptions
column15: and reveals how an evolving scientific understanding informed the Renaissance worldview.:::Completion of 4.0 credits:VIC242H1

column1: REN338H1:Renaissance in the City::24S:An interdisciplinary course exploring the history
column5: and music of the Renaissance in one or more cities from ca. 1400-1650. The course will investigate how local political and social-historical contexts shape ideas and cultural forms
column6: and so illustrate the process and effects of cross-fertilization in the Renaissance period.:::REN240Y1
column7: or another course in Renaissance Studies:VIC338H1:Humanities:

column1: REN340H1:The Global Renaissance::24S:The Renaissance is when the world became truly global. In this course
column2: we examine how the production of stories
column4: and ideas was affected by early globalization. In particular
column5: we explore cross-cultural encounters and exchanges established between early modern Asia
column8: and Europe along networks of trade
column10: and oppression. We will pay particular attention to how early globalization was shaped by power structures and by the intersection of race

column2: Men and Children::24S:A study of the changing conception of the human self in the Renaissance
column3: and of its representation by major authors: Erasmus

column1: REN342H1:Women and Writing in the Renaissance::24S:Focusing on writers from various geographical areas
column2: the course examines a variety of texts by early modern women (for example
column5: and poetry) so as to explore the female experience in a literate society
column6: with particular attention to how women constructed a gendered identity for themselves against the backdrop of the cultural debates of the time.::::VIC342H1:Humanities:

column1: REN343H1:Sex and Gender::24S:An interdisciplinary approach to questions of gender and sexuality in early modern Europe
column2: with special focus on the representations of the sexual drive
column3: the gender roles of men and women
column4: and varieties of sexual experience in the literature and art of the period.::::VIC343H1

column1: REN343Y0:Sex and Gender:::An interdisciplinary approach to questions of gender and sexuality in early modern Europe
column2: with special focus on the representations of the sexual drive
column3: the gender roles of men and women
column4: and varieties of sexual experience in the literature and art of the period. (Offered as part of the Summer Abroad program)::::VIC343Y0:Humanities:

column1: REN344H1:Renaissance Narrative::24S:Focuses on analysis of short stories and longer prose works including
column2: in English translation: Boccaccio's stories of love
column3: fortune and human intelligence in the Decameron; Rabelais' humorous parody of high culture in Gargantua; the tragic tale of Romeo and Juliet; and the adventures of picaresque rogues in Lazarillo de Tormes and Nashe's Unfortunate Traveler.::::VIC344H1:Humanities:

column1: REN345H1:Media and Communications in the Early Modern Era::24S:This course examines the various media (printing press
column4: preaching) and social and political forces (family and political networks
column7: etc.) that conditioned the communication of ideas in early modern society.::::VIC345H1:Humanities:

column1: REN346H1:The Idea of the Renaissance::24S:This course examines the changing views of the Renaissance
column2: from the earliest definitions by poets and painters to the different understandings of contemporary historians. We will pay attention to the interests and biases that have informed the idea of the Renaissance as an aesthetic
column6: and Eurocentric phenomenon.:Completion of 4.0 credits::At least 0.5 credit in the art
column9: or philosophy of fifteenth or sixteenth century Europe:VIC346H1:Humanities:
