column4: and basic techniques for conducting language interviews. (Offered in alternate years):SPA120Y1 or  SPA220Y1 or  SPA219Y1 or Permission of the Department::SPA221H1/ SPA322H1::Humanities:

column1: SPA352H1:Court and Country in Early Modern Spain::24L:Representative texts (such as ballads

column1: SPA368H1:Spanish and the Empire: Migration in Language and Literature::24L:This interdisciplinary approach considers broad cultural consequences resulting from the contact of Spanish with the American indigenous languages. Current cultural and linguistic theories on language contact are used to analyze sixteenth to eighteenth-century Spanish texts

column1: SPA377H1:Central American Literature: Narratives of War::24L:The 70s and 80s represent a period of armed struggle
column3: and revolution in most of Central America. Through the study of specific novels

SPA420H1:Advanced Grammar::36L:Linguistic analysis with the objective of improving students' command of Spanish grammar. Advanced review of traditional grammatical topics
column2: including the verbal and pronominal systems
column3: and Spanish copulas and embedded clauses. This course assumes familiarity with the grammatical terminology introduced in  SPA320Y1.:SPA219Y1 or  SPA320Y1

column1: SPA421H1:The Structure of Spanish::36L:Study of Spanish morphology and syntax: syntactic categories in Spanish
column2: the structure and interpretation of simple and complex sentences. (Offered in alternate years):SPA420H1

column1: SPA422H1:Sociolinguistics of Spanish::24L:Study of linguistic variation across the Spanish-speaking world; central issues in phonological
column4: analyzed from a geographical as well as from a social point of view. (Offered in alternate years):SPA322H1 or permission of the department::SPA420H1::Humanities:

column1: SPA423H1:Spanish Phonology::24L/12T:Theoretical and experimental approaches to Spanish phonology. Topics include: Spanish phonemic inventory
column4: synchronic and diachronic variation. Methods of data collection and analysis in the discipline
column5: with practical applications. (Offered in alternate years):SPA322H1 or permission of the Department::SPA420H1::Humanities:

column1: SPA424H1:Experimental Approaches to Hispanic and Lusophone Linguistics::12P/24S:This course introduces students to theoretically grounded experimental approaches in the field of linguistics
column2: with a particular focus on Hispanic and Lusophone linguistics. Students will receive training in the use of different experimental and corpus analysis techniques and will discuss paradigmatic examples of research papers in the areas of phonetics-phonology and morpho-syntax. Throughout the course
column3: they will conduct their own research project under the supervision of a specialist in the field. The course can be taught in English
column4: Spanish and Portuguese.:SPA322H1/  PRT322H1::300-level SPA/PRT linguistic courses:::

column1: SPA425H1:History of the Spanish Language::24L:Have you ever doubted where Spanish came from? Or how did it become the language we know today? This course presents a detailed study of the external and internal history of the Spanish language in which this evolution occurred. Special attention will be paid to the linguistic progress of the language from its Latin roots to Modern Spanish and to the socio-cultural
column3: political and literary influence that have affected its linguistic evolution. The main features of the Spanish language evolution will be put in practice through a close reading of representative Medieval
column4: Renaissance and dialectal texts.:SPA320Y1 or  SPA219Y1 or permission of instructor:::::

column1: SPA427H1:Spanish Language Teaching as Reflective Practice::24L/6P:Practical introduction to planning
column3: and delivery of academic projects related to teaching of the Spanish language. This course concentrates on core communication skills that students will adapt and apply to various contexts and projects. Through experiential activities
column4: students will be able to deepen their understanding on how we negotiate institutional
column6: and global challenges in multilingual educational contexts.:SPA320Y1:SPA420H1:::Humanities:

column1: SPA435H1:Fictions of Contemporary Spain::24L:Study of major currents in narrative fiction during the last twenty years
column2: a period of return to democratic government
column3: the relaxing of censorship and the opening up of Spanish culture. Analysis of works from several generations of male and female writers. (Offered every three years):At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.::SPA258H1::Humanities:

column1: SPA439H1:Topics in Spanish Studies::24S:A course on specific topics in Spanish studies
column2: designed for advanced students. Course content and instructor are established on a yearly basis.:SPA220Y1/ SPA219Y1::SPA258H1::Humanities:

column1: SPA454H1:Cervantes: Don Quixote::36L:Detailed study of Don Quixote as a foundational text in the European literary tradition
column4: and literary techniques that inform the text.:SPA258H1;  SPA219Y1 or  SPA320Y1 or permission of the department::SPA352H1; Another 300-series half course in Spanish:SPA350Y1:Humanities:

column1: SPA467H1:Topics in Spanish-American Literature and Culture::24L:A course on a specific topic in Spanish American culture
column2: designed for advanced students. Course content and instructor are established on a yearly basis.:At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.::SPA258H1/ SPA259H1::Humanities:

column1: SPA475H1:21st Century Latin American Culture::24L:Contemporary Argentine and Mexican authors and visual artists will be studied through their work
column3: and also the institutional and discursive structures that facilitate and shape their production. In-class Skype discussions with some of the artists. (Offered every three years):At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.::SPA258H1/ SPA259H1::Humanities:

column1: SPA480H1:Icons and Iconography in Latin American Culture::24L:Production
column2: circulation and meaning of icons through Latin American literary and cultural contexts. Readings are selected from the period of independence to the present
column3: and focus on the transformative ideological charge of cultural objects across geographic space and history. Focuses on political and socio-economic tensions between popular and elite spheres of cultural production
column4: and on the risks and limits of iconographic representation. (Offered every three years):At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.::SPA258H1/ SPA259H1::Humanities:

column1: SPA482H1:20th-Century Spanish American Narrative::24L:Detailed study of the major movements in Spanish-American narrative
column6: through analysis of representative novels and short stories. (Offered every three years):At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.::SPA258H1/ SPA259H1::Humanities:

column1: SPA486H1:Contemporary Caribbean Literatures and Identities::24L:Literature studied as a socio-political space for the articulation of new concepts of cultural identity; examination of cultural change and aesthetic innovation in selected poetic
column3: and narrative texts from different national traditions (Cuba
column5: Puerto Rico). (Offered every three years):At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.::SPA258H1/ SPA259H1::Humanities:

column1: SPA489H1:Latin American Transculturations::36L:This course integrates a series of contemporary debates in Latin American cultural studies with analysis of its transdisciplinary history and global permutations. Key topics of investigation within these debates may include indigeneity; coloniality
column7: and the popular; gender and sexuality; and the production of race.:SPA258H1;  SPA219Y1/ SPA320Y1::Another 300-series half-course in literature::Humanities:

column3: and written approval of the Undergraduate Coordinator::::Humanities:

column1: STA130H1:An Introduction to Statistical Reasoning and Data Science::24L/24P:This course
column2: intended for students considering a program in Statistical Sciences
column3: discusses the crucial role played by statistical reasoning in solving challenging problems from natural science
column8: using a combination of logical thinking
column11: and oral and written discussion and analysis.::MAT135H1/  MAT136H1/  MAT137Y1/  MAT157Y1
column12: ( CSC108H1/ equivalent programming experience)/  CSC110Y1/  CSC148H1 *Note: the corequisite may be completed either concurrently or in advance.::Any of  STA220H1/  STA255H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA261H1/  ECO220Y1/  ECO227Y1/  STAB22H3/  STA220H5/  STAB57H3/  STA258H5/  STA260H5/  ECO220Y5/  ECO227Y5/  STAA57H3 taken previously or concurrently:Science:

column1: STA197H1:Thinking Better with Statistics::24S:This course explores how our statistical intuitions and ways of thinking can let us down. There’s no need to be a math whiz to be a better statistical thinker. Everyone can become a more critical consumer of claims presented in media
column2: advertisements and by politicians—especially those relevant to our own health and wealth. This course uses real-world examples and tours common and avoidable statistical traps and tricks. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Science:

column1: STA198H1:Probabilities Everywhere::24S:This course examines the meaning and mathematics of probabilities
column2: and how they arise in our everyday lives. Specific topics may include: the nature of coincidences
column11: and Monte Carlo algorithms. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Grade 12 Mathematics::::Science:

column1: STA199H1:Statistical Evidence: Truth or Myth?::24S:This course explores the impact Statistics has made and continues to make on everyday life through science
column3: and the modern methods for information processing. Statistical principles will be illustrated using examples from real life including business
column4: romance and health. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Science:

column1: STA201H1:Why Numbers Matter::36L:This course teaches non-science students the importance of quantitative reasoning to many different areas. It explores a variety of applications to such diverse subjects as economics
column12: using only basic high school level mathematics combined with logical thinking.::::MAT133Y1/ MAT135H1/ MAT136H1/ MAT137Y1/ MAT157Y1/( MATA29H3

column2: emphasizing exploratory data analysis for univariate and bivariate data
column5: estimation and tests of hypothesis in one-sample and comparative two-sample studies. A statistical computing package is used but no prior computing experience is assumed. Note:  STA220H1 does not count as a distribution requirement course.:::Grade 12 Mathematics and one University course in BR= 3/ 4/ 5:ECO220Y1/  ECO227Y1/  GGR270H1/  IRW220H1/  PSY201H1/  SOC300Y1/  STA261H1/  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA288H1/  EEB225H1/  STAB22H3/  STAB57H3/  STA215H5/  STA220H5/  ECO220Y5/  ECO227Y5/  STA258H5/  STA260H5::

column1: STA288H1:Statistics and Scientific Inquiry in the Life Sciences::36L/18P:Introduction to statistics and its connection to all stages of the scientific inquiry process. Issues around data collection
column2: analysis and interpretation are emphasized to inform study design and critical assessment of published research. Statistical software is used to conduct descriptive and inferential statistics to address basic life sciences research questions.:BIO230H1/ BIO255H1:::STA220H1

STA302H1:Methods of Data Analysis I::36L:Introduction to data analysis with a focus on regression. Initial Examination of data. Correlation. Simple and multiple regression models using least squares. Inference for regression parameters
column2: confidence and prediction intervals. Diagnostics and remedial measures. Interactions and dummy variables. Variable selection. Least squares estimation and inference for non-linear regression.:STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA255H1/  STA261H1/  ECO227Y1/  STAB57H3/  STA258H5/  STA260H5/  ECO227Y5;  CSC108H1/  CSC110Y1/  CSC120H1/  CSC148H1/  CSCA08H3/  CSCA20H3/  CSCA48H3/  CSC108H5/  CSC148H5;  MAT223H1/  MAT224H1/  MAT240H1/  MATA22H3/  MATA23H3/  MAT223H5/  MAT240H5/  MATB24H3/  MAT224H5:::STAC67H3

column1: STA304H1:Surveys
column2: Sampling and Observational Data::36L:Design of surveys
column4: randomized response surveys. Techniques of sampling; stratification
column7: estimates of population mean and variances
column8: ratio estimation. Observational data; correlation vs. causation
column10: sources of bias.:ECO227Y1/  STA255H1/  STA261H1/  STA248H1/  STA238H1/  STAB57H3/  STA258H5/  STA260H5/  ECO227Y5:::STAC50H3

column1: STA305H1:Design and Analysis of Experiments::36L:Experiments vs observational studies
column2: experimental units. Designs with one source of variation. Complete randomized designs and randomized block designs. Factorial designs. Inferences for contrasts and means. Model assumptions. Crossed and nested treatment factors
column3: random effects models. Analysis of variance and covariance. Sample size calculations.:STA302H1/ STAC67H3/ STA302H5:::STAC50H3

column1: STA313H1:Data Visualization::24L/12P:An introduction to data visualization and the use of visual and interactive representations of data to support human cognition. This course covers visualization techniques and algorithms based on principles from graphic design
column4: and human-computer interaction. Topics include: graphic design
column8: and ethics. Computational tutorials involve design review
column10: and testing of information visualizations.:CSC108H1/  CSC110Y1/  CSC120H1/  CSC148H1;  STA238H1/  STA248H1/  STA261H1/  ECO227Y1::::Science:

column4: and logistic regression; principal components analysis; stochastic gradient descent; decision trees and random forests; k-means clustering and nearest neighbour methods. column2: conditional expectation/probability and consequences. Various types of convergence leading to proofs of the major theorems in basic probability. column1: STA365H1:Applied Bayesian Statistics::36L:Bayesian inference has become an important applied technique and is especially valued to solve complex problems. This course first examines the basics of Bayesian inference. From there
column3: computational methods and how to make inferences on complex data problems.:STA302H1/ STAC67H3/ STA302H5::::Science:

STA410H1:Statistical Computation::36L:Programming in an interactive statistical environment. Generating random variates and evaluating statistical methods by simulation. Algorithms for linear models
column3: and Bayesian inference. Statistical algorithms such as the Kalman filter and the EM algorithm. Graphical display of data.:STA302H1/  STAC67H3/  STA302H5;  CSC108H1/  CSC110Y1/  CSC120H1/  CSC148H1/  CSCA08H3/  CSCA48H3/  CSCA20H3/  CSC108H5/  CSC148H5;  MAT223H1/  MAT224H1/  MAT240H1/  MATA22H3/  MATA23H3/  MAT223H5/  MAT240H5/  MATB24H3/  MAT224H5::::Science:

column1: STA414H1:Statistical Methods for Machine Learning II::36L:Probabilistic foundations of supervised and unsupervised learning methods such as naive Bayes
column3: and logistic regression. Gradient-based fitting of composite models including neural nets. Exact inference
column5: and Marko chain Monte Carlo. Variational autoencoders and generative adversarial networks.:STA314H1/  CSC411H1/  CSC311H1/ ( STA314H5

column1: STA422H1:Theory of Statistical Inference::36L:This course examines current theory of statistical inference
column2: particularly likelihood-based methods and Bayesian methods with an emphasis on resolving present conflicts; log-model expansion and asymptotics are primary tools.:STA355H1::::Science:

column1: STA437H1:Methods for Multivariate Data::24L/12P:Practical techniques for the analysis of multivariate data; fundamental methods of data reduction with an introduction to underlying distribution theory; basic estimation and hypothesis testing for multivariate means and variances; regression coefficients; principal components and partial
column2: multiple and canonical correlations; multivariate analysis of variance; profile analysis and curve fitting for repeated measurements; classification and the linear discriminant function.:STA302H1/ STAC67H3/ STA302H5::MAT224H1/ MAT247H1:STAD37H3

column1: STA442H1:Methods of Applied Statistics::36L:Advanced topics in statistics and data analysis with emphasis on applications. Diagnostics and residuals in linear models
column4: additional topics such as random effects models
column8: introduced as needed in the context of case studies.:STA303H1/( STAC67H3

column1: STA447H1:Stochastic Processes::36L:Discrete and continuous time processes with an emphasis on Markov
column2: Gaussian and renewal processes. Martingales and further limit theorems. A variety of applications taken from some of the following areas are discussed in the context of stochastic modeling: Information Theory

column1: STA450H1:Topics in Statistics::36L:Topics of current research interest are covered. Topics vary from year to year. As the necessary academic preparation for this course may vary from year to year

column1: STA465H1:Theory and Methods for Complex Spatial Data::36L:Data acquisition trends in the environmental
column2: physical and health sciences are increasingly spatial in character and novel in the sense that modern sophisticated methods are required for analysis. This course will cover different types of random spatial processes and how to incorporate them into mixed effects models for Normal and non-Normal data. Students will be trained in a variety of advanced techniques for analyzing complex spatial data and
column4: will be able to undertake a variety of analyses on spatially dependent data
column5: understand which methods are appropriate for various research questions
column6: and interpret and convey results in the light of the original questions posed.:STA302H1/ STAC67H3/ STA302H5

column4: and extensions to competing risks and multistate modelling.:STA303H1::::Science:

column1: TRN125Y1:Contemporary Issues in Health Science::48S:Can the immune system be strengthened? Are some diseases incurable? What is the best way to stop the spread of a virus? This course examines the scientific principles underlying contemporary issues in the science of human health with the goal of exposing students to the current state of biomedical research. We will develop three distinct types of understanding that are essential to literacy about the science of human health: the basic concepts in science; the nature of scientific research; and the rules that govern how scientists do their work. This course will explore topics such as stem cells
column6: and personalized medicine. Restricted to first-year students admitted to the Trinity One Program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::TRN225Y1:::Science:

column1: TRN135Y1:Science and Social Choice::48S:Many of the decisions we make as a society rely on advances in scientific knowledge. In this course
column2: we will discuss a number of contemporary medical topics that involve complex scientific discoveries about health
column5: and infection. We will consider genes and study the medical implications of our growing understanding of the human genome. We will study a number of recent cases in order to explore how scientific findings influence decision-making in hospitals and the selection of social policies. We will also discuss the background forces that shape medical research and how this affects the kinds of health problems that are prioritized. The objective of this course is to develop a solid understanding of biological concepts related to human health and consider them in their wider social and ethical contexts. Restricted to first-year students admitted to the Trinity One Program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::TRN136Y1:::Science

column1: TRN136Y1:Canadian Health Policy in the Global Context::48S:In this course we consider when our health policies support the highest standards of medical care
column2: consistent with the latest discoveries in medical research. We examine the ways in which debates around ethics
column3: effectiveness and efficiency shape global and national health policy. We begin by exploring the most important advancements in global health policy over the past two decades. We then assess Canada’s experience in providing health care
column4: identifying lessons for national policy reform and for Canada’s role as a leader in global health research and policy. We explore a range of health challenges including universal health care
column15: violence against women and mental health. Restricted to first-year students admitted to the Trinity One Program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::TRN135Y1:::Science

column1: TRN140Y1:Ethics
column3: and Nature::48S:This course introduces students to ethical issues arising from the way humans interact with nature. Students will study some theoretical approaches for evaluating how human society affects the planet
column5: and the other animals. Theories will be drawn from philosophy
column8: and will include Western and non-Western approaches to living in harmony with one’s environment. Key themes may include speciesism – the idea that human needs are the most important – as well as overpopulation
column11: and responsible resource management. The course will also look at how social policy shapes human choices and whether sustainability initiatives should be pursued through the public or private sector. The course will also discuss the spiritual connection between humans and the environment and how society can be organized to promote access to nature in urban communities. Restricted to first-year students admitted to the Trinity One Program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::TRN141Y1::::

column1: TRN141Y1:Environmental Science and Pathways to Sustainability::48S:This course introduces students to fundamental issues in environmental science with a multi-disciplinary focus on human impacts on physical and biological systems
column2: and on identifying pathways to sustainability. Key themes will include energy and resources
column5: contaminants and protecting biodiversity in the context of the Anthropocene. The course challenges students to apply the scientific method to environmental monitoring
column6: research and problem solving through project design
column7: data collection and analysis. The course also emphases information literacy
column8: skills to distinguish science from pseudo-science
column9: and considerations around representation of environmental science in the media. Restricted to first-year students admitted to the Trinity One Program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::TRN140Y1::::

column1: TRN150Y1:National versus International::48S:The international system today faces extraordinary challenges. Understanding these challenges requires understanding the past. This seminar course briefly reviews the origins and development of the international system from the 17th century through the age of empires and the great wars of the 20th century. It then concentrates on the clash of nationalism with internationalism in the world since 1945
column2: looking at such issues as what drives nationalism and what alternatives there are to it. We will study ideas and ideologies as well as the institutions that make up the current geopolitical world. Restricted to first-year students admitted to the Trinity One Program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::TRN151Y1:::Social Science:

column1: TRN151Y1:Global Governance::48S:Terrorism
column2: the proliferation of arms (including weapons of mass destruction)
column6: and the rise of non-state actors all pose challenges to statecraft and the management of global order. This seminar course explores the changing dynamics of global politics and the responses to them by states (and others). Topics will include an examination of new forms of international collaboration that have developed in the wake of crises in the years following the Second World War. Restricted to first-year students admitted to the Trinity One Program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::TRN150Y1/  TRN152Y1:::Social Science:

column1: TRN152Y1:Justice & Global Conflict::48S:Modern states face both new and familiar challenges to protecting national security. National insecurity threatens a country’s capacity to protect the well-being of its citizens while at the same time participating in international organizations and treaties. This course explores the origins and management of international conflict from the 17th to the 21st century
column2: focusing on the precursors to war and the markers of peace. We will also consider the ways in which our current global world order promotes and preserves justice between and within nations. Students will consider different theoretical approaches to justice between nations
column3: and apply them to recent security issues. By studying the history of conflict and the difference between justice and injustice students will gain a deeper understanding of how current geopolitical actors can structure and affect the prospects for security policy reform moving forward. Restricted to first-year students admitted to the Trinity One Program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::TRN151Y1::::

column1: TRN160Y1:Public Policy and the Public Good::48S:This course examines the sense of the public good that undergirds Canada's domestic and international obligations. We examine the notion of the “public” through investigating possible answers to a central political question: what is the purpose of government? Drawing on readings in philosophy and political theory
column2: the course considers a variety of approaches to defining the nature of the public good and how policy makers should respond when competing goods (e.g.
column3: freedom and security) clash with each other. In addition
column4: the course looks at the treaties and conventions that articulate the responsibilities of signatory nations regarding challenges such as climate change mitigation
column6: and foreign aid. Students will learn how international agreements either compel or encourage participation and multilateral cooperation in the absence of robust enforcement mechanisms. Restricted to first-year students admitted to the Trinity One Program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::TRN161Y1/  TRN162Y1:::Humanities:

column1: TRN161Y1:Making Public Policy Work::48S:How do we know what kinds of public policy will work and what will not? How do we assess the effectiveness of a policy? An historical examination of ways in which Canadian governments have addressed a range of policy problems. Case studies of areas of federal and provincial activity today. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Trinity One::::Social Science:

TRN162Y1:Political Economy and Social Inequality::48S:What is the relationship between capitalism and democracy? How can understanding rational choice theory inform public policy? This course will introduce students to the methods of studying the interplay between economics and politics. We will focus on specific topics to guide our quantitative analysis
column5: and social stratification. We will analyse empirical results while developing critical skills for interpreting economic data and research. The course also considers global economic dynamics
column7: as well as the political-economic dimensions of setting global policies. By the end of the course
column8: students will have a better understanding of global political economy
column9: and its connection the fields of international relations and public policy. Restricted to first-year students admitted to the Trinity One Program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::TRN160Y1::::

column1: TRN170Y1:Ethics and the Creative Imagination::48S:A seminar course that explores ethical issues through the study of works of the creative imagination that pose or provoke questions of right and wrong
column3: justice and injustice. The selected works will be drawn from such fields as literature
column5: and the visual and performing arts. Open only to students admitted to Trinity One. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Trinity One::::Humanities:

column1: TRN171Y1:Ethics and the Public Sphere::48S:What does it mean to be morally required to do something? What rights do we have over ourselves
column5: we will read texts from philosophy
column8: cultural studies and beyond that engage with the theme of ethics in the public arena. These will provide valuable analytic tools as we go on to confront contemporary issues that raise urgent ethical questions. Restricted to first-year students admitted to the Trinity One Program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::TRN172Y1:::Humanities:

column1: TRN172Y1:Ethics and the Law::48S:What is the relationship between moral values and the law? What role does the law play in enabling people to live better lives? Are legal institutions and actors subject to higher ethical standards? In this course we will read texts from legal theory and political philosophy to try to explain the connection between ethics and the law. This will provide the basis for thinking about some historical and contemporary legal cases
column2: as well as ethical issues judges
column4: and lawmakers face in their professional roles. Restricted to first-year students admitted to the Trinity One Program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::TRN171Y1:::Humanities:

column1: TRN191H1:Disaster and Terrorism: Religion and Ethics at Ground Zero::24S:In response to contemporary terrorist attacks and natural disasters
column3: “The world will never be the same!” How should such statements be evaluated? What impact do they have on social and political life? This course explores religious and cultural responses to human tragedy and cultural shock. Discussion will attend to debates over the meaning of suffering
column6: and the role of media in covering such events. These themes are engaged from the perspectives of ethics
column9: and theology. The course focuses on popular responses to events that include: the Lisbon Earthquake of 1755
column13: the Japanese experiences of Hiroshima and Fukushima
column15: and more recent examples of terrorism and disaster. Attention will be given to concerns such as the impact of trauma on social and political debate
column16: the function of religious discourse in the face of tragedy
column18: and the relationship between religion and violence. A thematic concern throughout the course will be the nature of ethical commitment in the midst of confusion and social disruption. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: TRN192H1:Public Health in Canada: Health for the 21st Century::24L:This course deals with preventive care and population health. It will also move into new areas like healthcare and the environment (climate change) and the greening of healthcare. It will look at health as an extension of democracy – of how health extends individual rights beyond the political realm to the social realm
column2: of how it can build social capital and knit populations together. It will look at areas inimical to health
column3: ‘detriments to health’ and how economic inequality can lead to health inequality. Along with this it will look at ways of empowering the individual
column4: the public as agent and a role of public engagement by major institutions. It will also push beyond the popular determinants of health to engage students in a paradigm on next steps
column5: the future challenges in population health. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: TRN193H1:Canadian Health Policy: Past
column2: Present and Future::24L:This is a health systems course. It deals with illness care
column4: and health insurance. It will take a comparative and historical approach. We will look at the genesis of Canadian healthcare
column5: our benefits and those other countries provide (e.g.
column7: dental care). We will look at indirect contributors like childcare and basic income. We will examine the public-private debate. We will also take some novel approaches. One is that the university has an expanded role in the 21st century
column9: a role that includes healthcare. Recent academic literature on healthcare notes that it is nation-building. We will look at why. We will examine some cutting-edge ideas
column12: the concept of customer-owners. We will explore whether our healthcare system needs to be anchored by ‘institutions of excellence’ and identify these. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: TRN194H1:Literature and Wicked Problems::24L:This course explores contemporary literature in relation to the interdisciplinary framework of “wicked problems.” Research emphasizes that complex
column3: like government relations with Indigenous peoples or human impacts on the climate
column4: involve interconnected systems and require approaches that cross disciplines and types of knowledge. The course examines the role of literary works (mostly 21st-century fiction) in addressing these issues of pressing concern to students as global citizens. Critical thinking
column5: scholarly reading and database research are foundational skills that this course strengthens in order to prepare students for their writing in disciplines across the university. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: TRN195H1: The Literature of Heroes and Horrors::24L:This course explores contemporary literary works that redefine heroism in light of personal and cultural trauma. What does recent literature (mostly 21st-century fiction) show us about the nature of heroism in our time? To answer this question
column2: the course examines theories of psychological trauma
column3: studies in the field of positive psychology
column4: and research on gothic and dystopian literature. Critical thinking
column5: scholarly reading and database research are foundational skills that the course strengthens in order to prepare students for their writing in disciplines across the university. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: TRN196H1:Joy and Resistance in Diverse Storytelling::24L:"Can we speak about joy for once?" In contemporary literature from Black
column2: Indigenous and People of Colour (BIPOC) authors across Canada and Turtle Island
column3: there is a resurgence in diasporic stories that capture the joy and resistance of carving space for community against the mechanisms of the state. This course explores how BIPOC literature has intersected with social problems and activist movements
column4: creating spaces for readers to reflect on their own lived experiences. Students will expand their creative thinking
column5: critical reading and scholarly writing skills through multi-modal assignments that offer connections to current issues and community knowledge. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: TRN197H1:In the Shadow of the Vikings: Depictions of the Early Norse in Medieval
column3: and Post-Modern Culture::24L:Although rarely attested during the historical era when they were active
column4: since the early nineteenth century the word “Viking” has been popularly applied to describe groups of Scandinavian adventurers who marauded along the frontiers of Medieval Europe: in this respect
column5: the image of “the Viking” may be regarded as much a modern
column7: creation. The legacy of historical “Viking activities” was a factor in the development of modern nation states in Scandinavia and the Baltic region
column8: and their contributions to the heritage of people residing in Britain
column11: and even the Atlantic coast of Canada have been and continue to be cited to the present day. Aspects of culture attributed to “the Vikings”—their assumed independence
column14: and tenacity in the face of adversity
column15: as well as the occult characteristics of their cosmology—have
column22: and persist in present day literature
column25: sport and popular culture as well. Why and how do elements of historic Viking culture continue to evoke traditions and characteristics popularly attributed to “the Vikings”? What are some implications of “Viking-ness” for those people in the post-Viking Age past and/or present who we may regard—or may regard themselves—as the “cultural descendants” of the Vikings? In this seminar
column26: participants will study selected cultural artifacts of the “post-Viking Age
column28: to observe how various “post-Viking Age” cultures and subcultures have selectively appropriated elements of the “Viking” past. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: TRN198H1:The Viking Phenomenon: Commerce
column4: 7th – 15th Century::24L:Perspectives on the impact that the Scandinavian raiders and traders popularly referred to as “Vikings” had on European and World history continue to develop as the work of historians
column7: and scientists expands our understanding of the past. Recent research has revised the traditional view of the “Vikings” as primarily marauding warriors; in its place
column8: a more complex and nuanced conception of the implications that “Viking activity” had on the social
column10: and political development of the peoples with whom they came in contact has emerged. This seminar will consider the relationship between the traditional conception of the “Viking warrior” and recent research that suggests the broader impact that the “Viking Phenomenon” had upon the economic revival and sociopolitical development of medieval Europe and its frontiers. In the course of the seminar
column11: we will examine a selection of historical records and information concerning artifacts of the material culture of “The Viking Age” in order to better understand the activities of early medieval “Vikings
column13: but also as agents of commerce
column16: and rulers. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: TRN199H1:Classical Social and Political Thought from the 18th Century Enlightenment to the 20th Century::24L:We begin with European social and political thought during the 18th century
column2: including ideas of enlightenment and revolution. We move on to the 19th century to engage with the critical Marxist theorisation of the new “capitalist” social and political formation
column3: and look at the reception of the Marxist view in the 20th century
column4: all of which continues to affect the character of Western social and political thought. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities

column4: and construct arguments in ordinary English prose. Second term: one or more discipline-related modes of reasoning (e.g.

column2: Present and Future::24S:This course explores the nature and impact of public health policy in Canada. The course describes the origins of Canadian health policy

TRN250Y1:Empire
column3: and the History of International Relations::24L/48T:Our modern world has its foundations in the development of a complex and changing system of international behaviours

column7: this course offers an introductory historical survey using multiple perspectives and diverse settings
column8: paying special attention to the dissolution of empire
column10: and the creation of international order. How global transformations were experienced
column11: not only at the highest levels of power

column1: UNI101H1:Citizenship in the Canadian City::36S:Who belongs? Who governs? Who decides? In this course
column2: you will examine the concepts of citizenship
column6: and belonging. You will address topics such as Indigenous sovereignty claims
column9: and greening the city. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: UNI102H1:Performing the City I::36S:In this course we learn about different practices of performative engagement with the city and experiment with them through exercises and creative activities. The goal is to gain
column2: through this mode of embodied engagement with the city
column3: a critical understanding of urban space as a diverse social
column5: and physical environment. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: UNI103H1:Gradients of Health in an Urban Mosaic::36S:In this course
column2: you will examine how Toronto’s varied communities access and use health care
column3: and how they may encounter barriers in doing so. You will study how economic disparities
column5: and government policies affect health policy and the right to access resources. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: UNI104H1:Sex in the City::36S:You will learn about the sexual politics of the city and how cities and their neighbourhoods become sexualized and desexualized spaces. In Sex in the City
column2: you will examine what “sex” means to Toronto’s varied
column3: multicultural communities by looking at urban space
column6: safety and health resources and more. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: UNI106H1:Performing the City II::36S:Further exploration of connections between the performing arts
column3: and cultural diversity; complementing  UNI102H1. How does theatrical performance affect how people perceive the city? What are the alternatives to established theatres
column4: and how does community activism inform performing arts in Toronto? Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: UNI197H1:Hamilton: Musical and History::24S:This course examines the American revolution and its reception in the musical “Hamilton.” The American revolution generated multiple stories that included and excluded actors
column4: and more. This course delves into the American revolution and the diversity of those engaged in it and affected by it. The songs
column6: and reception of the musical “Hamilton” are a key resource for exploring the events and role of the American Revolution. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: UNI198H1:Why Go to University? The Changing Role and Purpose of Higher Education::24S:Is higher education about job preparation or about giving students an opportunity to learn about themselves and the world around them? Can higher education in Canada achieve both these aims? This course engages with the spirited conversations and scholarly debates about the ideals of a liberal arts education and how these connect with ancient and contemporary arguments about citizenship. We explore the impact on higher education of globalization and what some call the “corporatization” of universities. Students will be encouraged to think
column3: research and write about various models of higher education and explore questions suggested by these debates. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: UNI199H1:The Construction of Race in America: A History::24S:The course will explore the origins of racial categories in America. Drawing on primary sources such as memoirs
column3: and government records as well as writings by scholars
column4: we will examine how beliefs about these categories changed over time and with what consequences for the unfolding of American history. Arriving at the present day
column5: we will consider such contradictory developments as the accelerating influence of Black Lives Matter and the headline-grabbing white nationalism on display at the “Unite the Right” rally in Charlottesville
column8: 2017. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

URB234H1:Cities in Popular Culture::24L:By exploring different popular culture phenomena such as the emergence of hip-hop in the Bronx
column4: this course works to examine the contributions of popular culture in shaping our understandings of cities (as well as providing different perspectives of the city and the urban experience than is generally captured in scholarly/academic literature). Popular culture becomes a vehicle by which we will explore different aspects of urban life and urban representation.:Completion of 4.0 credits:::INI234H1:Social Science:

column1: URB235H1:A Multidisciplinary Introduction to Urban Studies I: Theoretical Foundations of City Building::24L:Focuses on the theoretical foundations of urbanization
column4: with particular attention on global urban growth
column9: and economic development. These topics are explored through a multidisciplinary lens
column10: with an emphasis on understanding urban transitions over time and their meaning for contemporary urban experience.:Completion of 4.0 credits
column11: including 1.0 credit from one of the following four course groups. Economics:  ECO101H1

column1: URB236H1:A Multidisciplinary Introduction to Urban Studies II: Urban Challenges and Theoretical Application::24L:Cities are centres of innovation and creative energy
column2: but they also face significant and pressing challenges. This course explores various urban issues including inequality
column5: while also examining the ways in which municipal governments and urban citizens are imagining and implementing potential solutions to these challenges.:URB235H1:::INI235Y1

column1: URB333H1:Social Justice in the City::24L:How do power and dominance consolidate in urban settings? How do individuals and communities contest this consolidation
column2: and claim spaces and rights in the city? These questions will be taken up through a range of critical approaches
column7: and anarchist perspectives. Students will have the opportunity to carry out interview-based research on an issue of equality and social justice that matters to them.::::INI333H1:Social Science:

column1: URB334H1:Urban Field Course::12S:Students will have the opportunity to travel to a destination city for a week-long examination of specific social
column4: and/or environmental issues. The trip will include meetings with municipal representatives and other decision-makers (public and possibly private). The findings of the trip supplemented by bibliographic research and in-class discussion will form the basis of a major research essay. Each student is required to pay the cost of transportation and accommodation. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:URB235H1 and  URB236H1:::INI334H1:Social Science:

column1: URB335H1:City Challenges
column2: City Opportunities in a 21st Century Toronto::12L/12S:Over the last 50+ years
column3: Toronto has become a national and international centre of economic activity
column4: with a vibrant arts and culture scene and world-renowned research
column7: the City has become one of the most culturally diverse cities in the world. That said
column8: Toronto also struggles with deep inequalities along many different axes
column11: and many other challenges. This course provides a window into how the leadership at the City of Toronto think and approach these and other issues as the City works to plan for the recovery from COVID-19.:Completion of 9.0 credits::URB235H1

column14: City Opportunities in a 21st Century Toronto)

column1: URB336H1:Creative Cities::24L:A prominent thesis in the fields of planning and economic geography is that the presence of creative occupations in a city correlates positively with the overall health of urban regions. This course will investigate the nature of this link from theoretical and empirical perspectives and examine its potential usefulness in a planning/policy context.:::URB235H1/ URB236H1/ GGR124H1:INI336H1
URB337H1:Housing and Homelessness::24L:Toronto
column3: is characterized by a stark dichotomy: upscale residential and commercial development transforms the landscape
column4: even while increasing numbers of residents are forced to live on the streets
column7: or crowded into unaffordable and substandard housing. This course will examine that paradox and activism that is trying to achieve the federal government’s stated goal: “By 2030
column8: everyone in Canada has a home that they can afford and that meets their needs”. Through readings
column12: we will trace the links between housing
column14: and urban politics; review policies and trends at the municipal
column15: provincial/territorial and national levels; and connect with urban movements to contest displacement.:::GGR124H1/ ( URB235H1

column1: URB439H1:Cities and Mega-events: Place-making
column4: give cities the opportunity to showcase themselves to the world
column5: but the production of television-friendly urban images do much to obscure the processes
column6: compromises and social consequences in host cities. These events are powerful tools for city branding. They are also potential opportunities for social movements and other groups and individuals to highlight their own sets of concerns. This course will explore the challenges and opportunities that cities face in hosting such events.:Completion of 12.0 credits:::INI439H1;  INI430H1 (Advanced Topics in Urban Studies II: Cities and Mega-Events: Conflicts and Opportunity) offered in Winter 2014;  INI332H1;  INI432H1 (Special Topics in Urban Studies: Cities and Mega-Events)

column1: URB440H1:The Changing Culture of Regent Park::24L:This course is a collaboration with the organization Regent Park Focus Youth Media Arts Centre
column2: a not-for-profit organization that was established to counter negative stereotypes about the Regent Park community. Together
column3: University of Toronto students and Regent Park Focus youth members will learn about media projects initiated by young people across the world
column4: and how these creative forms of communication
column6: and expression spurred change and social movements in their respective communities. U of T students and Regent Park Focus youth will work together to create their own media project about the neighborhood.:9.0 credits::URB235H1

column1: URB442H1:Urban Studio: Public Participation in Policy Making::24S:This course will provide a broad overview of the roles of both the citizen and the professional practitioner in advancing effective and meaningful public participation in the policy-making process
column2: particularly as it relates to city planning. Through an examination of a mix of theoretical frameworks and case studies from Toronto and elsewhere
column3: you will gain an understanding of the ways in which effective public participation can contribute to the maintenance of a healthy democratic society while also exploring some of the key challenges and opportunities faced by public participation practitioners today. The course has two key objectives: to give you a practical understanding of all of the elements of an effective public participation process
column4: and to explore how public participation processes can be designed to be more inclusive and effective. In addition
column5: students will be able to apply this knowledge towards the development of a project or report for a client.:9.0 credits::URB235H1

column1: UTP100H1:Themes in World History::24L:Surveys the development of human societies from their origins to the present. Topics may include the environment
column3: the creation and nature of belief systems
column7: and the relationship between global patterns and local development. Restricted to students enrolled in the UTPrep program.::::IFP100H1/ IFP100Y1:Humanities:

column1: VIC101H1:Conflict Theory and Practice::24S:This course is a general orientation to conflict theory
column2: and develops a basic understanding of essential conflict resolution principles that will complement the study of conflict theory. The course will examine the differences between conflicts and disputes
column3: the functions and desirability of conflict
column4: and the conditions that facilitate conversion of conflicts from destructive to constructive. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: VIC102H1:Ethics and Choices in Times of Crisis::24S:This course examines a specific event
column3: in relation to the public sphere. The course will use events or an event as an entry point to discuss the nature of society including topics such as major revolutions
column5: the impact of the appearance of significant artistic or cultural works
column6: and the impact of technological changes. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::VIC102Y1:Humanities

column1: VIC105H1:Odysseys: The Search for Meaning::24S:Metaphors and motivations of journeying have long intrigued human beings as they have attempted to understand the meaning of their existence: the setting out
column2: the seeking for a desired object
column4: and the longing to return home. Through texts
column7: this course will explore some of the shaping journey-myths of our culture from classical
column9: medieval and modern sources. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: VIC106H1:Psychology and Society::24S:This course explores central developments and ongoing controversies in the scientific study of the human mind
column2: brain and behaviour. It examines topics such as: psychoanalysis
column7: and feminist perspectives. Goals include understanding the historical evolution and social relevance of scientific psychology. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::VIC206H1:Humanities

column1: VIC107H1:Evolution
column3: and Behaviour::24S:In this course we examine major episodes in the history of evolution and genetics in the twentieth century. Topics include Darwinian evolution
column6: and genetic screening and therapy. We will examine different views about the control of evolution and genetic manipulation in their socio-cultural-economic context and discuss the ethical and social implications of those views. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::VIC207H1:Humanities

column1: VIC108H1:Belonging
column3: and Indigenous Identity::24S:This course will examine a number of questions related to Indigenous identities as they have been constituted through collective belonging and cultural representation. Topics covered may include: language
column9: and the enduring legacy of colonialism. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::VIC108Y1:Humanities

column1: VIC109H1:Innovators and Their Ideas::24S:A study of the ideas and concerns of innovators who questioned traditional views and values. The course includes creative thinkers who challenged basic concepts on politics
column4: and society. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::VIC109Y1:Humanities:

column1: VIC110H1:Critical Perspectives on Society::24S:By means of short texts
column2: film or art works this course explores such themes as the effect of technology on the political
column4: the question of resistance through art and the role of violence in the social. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: VIC112H1:Puzzles
column2: Discovery and the Human Imagination::24S:There has never been a period of time
column3: nor has there ever been a culture
column4: without some kind of puzzle tradition. Are puzzles just playful artefacts
column5: intended merely to entertain? Or are they mirrors of something much more fundamental in human life? The course will take a close look at what puzzles tell us about the human mind and human culture. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::VIC112Y1:Humanities

column1: VIC113H1:Encountering Distant Climes: The Literature of Travel and Exploration::24S:This course will study accounts of world travelers and explorers from the Middle Ages to the present
column2: including representative examples drawn from the Age of Exploration
column5: and the contemporary genre of travel writing. Particular attention will be given to the trans-cultural nature of travel
column6: and the interactive aspects of the gulf between the observer and those observed. Students will analyze the diverse motivational factors behind excursions and expeditions
column7: and apply a critique to written accounts in light of such factors as self-discovery
column15: and eco-tourism. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: VIC114H1:Renaissance in Popular Culture::24S:This course explores the depiction of the Renaissance in a wide range of plays
column2: films and novels. The focus is on the exchange between film
column5: and on how the values and concerns of the present shape creative recreations of the past in popular culture. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::VIC114Y1:Humanities:

column1: VIC115H1:Imagined Power: Literature and Film::24S:In this course we will study a number of literary and cinematic works that take up questions of power
column5: and freedom. Our texts will be drawn from a long history
column6: and from many parts of the world. The sequence however will not be chronological. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::VIC115Y1:Humanities

column1: VIC116H1:Politics of the Pen::24S:A study of how literature challenges prevailing political beliefs and social norms. We will situate our discussion in the broader context of human rights and freedoms. We will examine cases where literature has been censored and writers have been imprisoned or driven into exile. Part of this course involves a community service-learning component. We will consider how this literature contributes to debate and advocacy around issues of social justice. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

VIC117H1:Understanding the Performing Arts: Interpretation and Expression::24S:This course examines two key issues about the performing arts that concern both artists and theorists: the nature of interpretation and of expression. What might we mean when we say that a work
column2: a piece of music or a dance for example expresses something? What is it to express? And what is the nature of interpretation? Are there any constraints or boundaries on interpretation? We will draw on both philosophers and non-philosophers to explore these sorts of questions. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: VIC119H1:Myths and Legends in Modern Contexts::24S:This course provides an introduction to modern forms of ancient narratives
column2: exploring the ways in which selected ancient literary sources and myths have been adapted to modern Canadian literature. Ancient narratives or ‘old stories’ are often reused
column3: reinterpreted or reconstructed in modern narratives and given new relevance in a contemporary context. Students will encounter sources and contexts of ancient narratives. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: VIC121H1:Evaluating Healthcare: Problems and Solutions::24S:This course introduces students to the study of healthcare by asking foundational questions about how evidence and knowledge are produced in the context of healthcare problems. Students will explore how different frameworks for clinical practise (e.g. Evidence-based Medicine
column2: Person-Centered Healthcare) conceptualize evidence and how different methodologies impact how healthcare research is conceived
column4: and understood. Students will learn to critically appraise healthcare research studies and assess their evidence value and implications for clinical practice. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: VIC122H1:Scientific Evidence in Public Policy::24S:This course investigates issues arising from the translation of scientific evidence for public consumption
column2: including in the development of public policy and in confronting problems of social and global significance. Areas of focus will include climate change
column4: and clinical medicine. Students will explore concepts including the perception and communication of risk
column7: and the use and abuse of scientific authority and “expertise” in public discourse. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: VIC134H1:Globalization::24S:This interdisciplinary course explores the contemporary character of globalization. The world is shrinking as money
column6: and information flow across national boundaries. Some commentators assert that a more tightly interconnected world can exacerbate financial disruptions
column7: worsen the gap between rich and poor nations
column11: and give unconstrained freedom to predatory corporations. Others proclaim that globalization - understood as capitalism and free markets - fosters economic growth
column14: and enhances human prospects for a better life
column15: in rich and poor countries alike
column16: in unprecedented ways. Our task is to evaluate the evidence and draw our own conclusions. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: VIC135H1:The Death of Meaning::24S:In The Origin of Species
column2: Darwin concluded there was no evidence to suggest that life was designed by a higher power. A corollary of this is that our lives lack any necessary purpose or meaning. Our readings will be directed to the question of what it means to lack ‘Meaning’. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: VIC136H1:How to Study Everyday Life::24S:An introduction to the academic study of everyday life. A cross-disciplinary discussion class drawing on a wide variety of examples from ordinary life
column3: and culture. We situate the apparently innocuous within larger patterns of social relations and social change. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: VIC137H1:Science and Science Fiction::24S:Based on reading and discussion of science fiction and popular science in the context of social issues
column2: this seminar course explores the fantastic visions of humanity's future inspired by scientific advances during the twentieth century. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: VIC141H1:Discovery and Revolution::24S:This course examines the emergence of a global modern world in relation to the upheavals of the Renaissance (1350-1700) and its discoveries and innovations in culture and society. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::VIC141Y1:Humanities:
VIC142H1:Machiavelli: The Politics of Power::24S:The name of Machiavelli unleashes powerful opinions and responses and conjures up trickery
column2: duplicity and cynicism. Yet Machiavelli himself is arguably the least Machiavellian of political figures of the Italian Renaissance. This course examines the writings of Niccolò Machiavelli
column3: placing them in their historical context in order to understand this most controversial figure of the Renaissance
column4: his influence and his lasting legacy. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::ITA198H1 (Machiavelli and Machiavellianism);  VIC141Y1:Humanities:

column1: VIC150Y1:School and Society::48S:This course will be about the social and historical role of the school. The course will examine schools and learning as social
column4: and economic phenomena. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC151Y1 and  PSY100H1:::Social Science:

column1: VIC151Y1:Theories and Practices of Teaching::48S:This course focuses on connecting theories and practice of teaching with a view to having students develop their personal understanding of teaching. Students will be involved in a practicum. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC150Y1 and  PSY100H1:::Humanities:

column9: and 1.0 credit in any 100-level course in ENG or FAH or PHL:::Humanities:

column1: VIC163H1:Cultural Forms and Their Meanings: People and Ideas::24S:A study of culture with a view to developing basic concepts with examples drawn from the visual arts
column5: and/or local urban artefacts. We will emphasize how contemporary thought has affected the practice of everyday life. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC162H1
column8: and 1.0 credit in any 100-level course in ENG or FAH or PHL:::Humanities:

column1: VIC164H1:Ideas and Their Consequences: Literary and Artistic Realms of the Imagination::24S:A study of the ideas and concerns of creative thinkers and their impact upon cultures. The course includes literary
column2: scientific and/or religious intellectuals from the major traditions. Attention to modes of reasoning
column3: cultural definition and expression. Emphasis on philosophical and artistic concepts. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC162H1
column6: and 1.0 credit in any 100-level course in ENG or FAH or PHL:::Humanities:

column1: VIC165H1:Ideas and Their Consequences: Isolation and Communion in Modern Culture::24S:A study of art
column3: as an essential mode of experience and knowledge
column4: in the context of contemporary and modern society. Along with literary artists
column5: the course includes writers on history and sociology and presents the interplay between artistic vision and socio-political situations. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC162H1
column8: and 1.0 credit in any 100-level course in ENG or FAH or PHL:::Humanities:

column1: VIC166H1:Common Vices and Neglected Virtues: Intro to Ethics of Character::24S:Vice is popular: a prestigious university press has brought out a series of seven books on the Seven Deadly Sins. This course examines such questions as the following. Are greed
column2: lust and gluttony just bad names for necessary and otherwise acceptable instincts? What is the place
column6: civility and the like? Are vices and virtues culturally determined or a matter of individual preference? Can character be taught
column7: or is it rather a matter of genes and luck? Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC167H1
column10: and 1.0 credit in any 100-level course in ANT or PHL or RLG:::Humanities:

column1: VIC167H1:Ideas and Fine Thoughts::24S:This course examines how political ideas are formed and developed through literature

column7: and 1.0 credit in any 100-level course in ANT or PHL or RLG:::Humanities

column1: VIC168H1:Identity and Equality in the Public Sphere::24S:This course explores current legal and philosophical debates around equality
column3: and the shaping of individual and group identities. It addresses the way values
column5: and identities have an impact on the public sphere of law and policy-making – and the ways in which law and policy
column7: shape our conceptions (and misconceptions) of people's identities. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC166H1
column10: and 1.0 credit in any 100-level course in ANT or PHL or RLG:::Social Science:

column1: VIC169H1:Ethical Living in a Pluralistic World::24S:This course examines different values
column3: and traditions relating to the natural and social world

column8: and 1.0 credit in any 100-level course in ANT or PHL or RLG:::Social Science:

column1: VIC170Y1:The Impact of Science on Our Society::48S:How rhetoric and statistical analysis are used to communicate scientific observations and theories to different audiences will be examined in lectures and seminars. Uncertainty
column5: random error and bias will be discussed using examples drawn from literature
column7: life and social sciences. Students will prepare a research grant application on a scientific topic of their own choice. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC171Y1 and 1.0 credit selected from first-year course offerings in the sciences (0.5 credit must be a BIO course):::Humanities

column1: VIC171Y1:Methodology
column2: Theory and Practice in the Natural Sciences::48S:An examination of scientific theories and their logic in life and physical sciences. Experimental design
column4: data analysis and modeling will be discussed using examples drawn from primary source material in the natural sciences. Students will prepare a research paper on a topic designed in consultation with the instructor. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC170Y1 and 1.0 credit selected from first-year course offerings in the sciences (0.5 credit must be a BIO course):::Humanities:

column1: VIC172Y1:Physical Sciences Today::48S:How is science performed and what enables scientific progress? What are our responsibilities as scientists? We base the discussion mostly on the development of microscopy tools. We look at how scientific discoveries affect and were affected by society. This course explores the complementary skills and knowledge needed by modern scientists. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC173Y1 and 1.0 credit selected from first-year course offerings in the sciences (0.5 credit must be a CHM
VIC173Y1:Philosophy of Science for Physical Scientists::48S:This course introduces students to some of the issues in the philosophy of science
column3: and in the philosophy of physics
column4: in particular. Topics include the scientific method and its controversies
column5: the meaning of time and its properties
column8: and quantum mechanics. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC172Y1 and 1.0 credit selected from first-year course offerings in the sciences (0.5 credit must be a CHM

column1: VIC181H1:Events in the Public Sphere: World Affairs::24S:This course will review issues in contemporary world affairs
column2: from the fall of the Berlin Wall to the present day. The course will examine the politics and practice of foreign policy decision making. Issues to be covered include the collapse of the Soviet Union
column4: and the conflicts in Afghanistan and Iraq. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC183H1

column1: VIC183H1:Individuals and the Public Sphere: Shaping Memory::24S:This course explores how public service and citizenship are developed. Topics may include the role of law and government

column2: Historiography and Making Cultural Memory::24S:A seminar course that examines the contribution of an individual or individuals to the public sphere. The course will explore how public service and citizenship are developed in social
column4: and cultural contexts. We will examine our evolving role in developing collective
column5: cultural and counter memory. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC181H1
column8: and 1.0 credit in any 100-level course in ECO

column1: VIC185H1:Events in the Public Sphere: Social Justice::24S:This course uses events to discuss the nature of society including major revolutions

column4: cultural and technological developments. Emphasis on our responsibilities towards social justice. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC181H1

column1: VIC186H1:The Art and Literature of Leadership 1::24S:What is a leader? Are leaders born or are they made
column2: and if they are made is there a craft to being able to lead others? Through works of art
column5: this course examines the various types of men and women who become leaders from natural-born talents to statesmen and state-crafters and individual entrepreneurs with the purpose of defining those qualities that make for the leaders of tomorrow. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC187H1

column3: and Sustainability: Introduction to Public Policy::24S:This course introduces policy applications of measurement tools and economic concepts by analyzing current issues in the news

column10: and education. Concepts from the philosophy and history of economic thought will be used to address such questions as: What is the nature of economic explanations? Do they tell us the truth about reality? Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC186Y1

column1: VIC188H1:Corporate Citizenship
column3: and Ethics::24S:Drawing together philosophical background readings with contemporary applications
column4: this course addresses issues of corporate social responsibility
column9: and considers how these topics intersect with a wide range of global practices. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC186Y1

column3: poet or dramatist has changed society and how we imagine our future. The course explores a number of paradigm cases of how the arts have interacted with social problems. Both historical and current examples of the role of the imaginative arts will be explored. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:Admission to Vic One:VIC191Y1 and 1.0 credit in any 100-level course in ARC or CIN or DRM or ENG or MUS or VIS:::Humanities:

column1: VIC191Y1:Artistic Creation and Public Issues::72S:This course addresses social issues through the exploration of creative activity and the imaginative arts. Topics will be discussed from historical

column1: VIC196H1:Renaissance Queens::24S:This course examines Renaissance queens and queenship by exploring historical and fictional queens and empresses. Topics may include the varied roles queens played within their societies
column2: their relationship with religious and political institutions
column3: the ways in which they negotiated sovereignty vis-a-vis the gender they embodied
column4: and all the ways in which queens were celebrated
column8: and communities of their time and today. Discussion will delve into broad questions around identity and politics and feature a broad range of case studies from Europe to colonial America and beyond. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: VIC197H1:Detective Fiction::24L:This course considers detective fiction from its inception in the late nineteenth century to the present day. Students will be introduced to canonical and lesser known authors of detective fiction
column3: and reception history. Course content may include mystery stories
column5: and critical writing on detective fiction. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::ITA197H1::

column1: VIC198H1:Posters and Propaganda::24L:How and when have political posters been used? What forms do they take? How have they changed over time? What can these visual artifacts tell us about the relationship between art and propaganda
column2: and about the political movements that have mobilized visual strategies to advance their aims? This course involves visits to several poster collections
column4: and highlights the role of the visual in societies past and present. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: VIC199H1:The Secret Life of Objects: Analyzing the Culture of Things::24S:This course will examine the materiality of objects with a view to understanding how artefacts are made
column4: and the importance of things to social and cultural life. An investigation of artefacts from various collections in and around the university will be undertaken to develop basic methods for the study
column5: description and analysis of material culture. In addition to hands-on exploration of objects
column6: topics may include antiquarians and their methods
column8: and materials in contemporary user-friendly design. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: VIC206H1:Psychology and Society::24S:This course explores central developments and ongoing controversies in the scientific study of the human mind
column2: brain and behaviour. It examines topics such as: psychoanalysis
column7: and feminist perspectives. Goals include understanding the historical evolution and social relevance of scientific psychology.::::VIC106H1:Humanities

column1: VIC207H1:Genetic Technologies: Scientific Promises and Ethical Dilemmas::24L/12T:This course examines the ethical dilemmas raised by new genetic technologies. It explores the scientific possibilities they open as well as the moral questions they raise. The topics covered might include: Eugenics

VIC245H1:Science Wars: Society and the Limits of Scientific Knowledge::24L:An introduction to competing conceptions of scientific knowledge and the role of sociocultural factors in shaping scientific methods
column3: and evidence. Can science provide objective knowledge of the external mind-independent world
column4: or are the empirical aspirations of science limited by the social
column8: and religious contexts that shape “science” itself? Can scientific knowledge reach certainty? How do sociocultural factors affect the process of theory acceptance? This course considers “science” as an epistemological battleground from 17th century debates on inductive reasoning to contemporary arguments about “alternative” science.::::::

column1: VIC246H1:Animal
column4: Monster::24L:This course introduces students to the history of natural history--or how thinkers (often called "naturalists") made sense of the world around them. Course readings
column6: and activities will explore changing perspectives on nonhuman nature across time
column7: from medieval bestiaries to early modern cabinets of curiosities
column8: from colonial botany to more recent legends of Yetis
column10: and other fantastical creatures of cryptozoology.:Completion of 4.0 credits::::Social Science:

column1: VIC248H1:Genetics in the Movies: Mad Scientists
column4: and Designer Babies::24L/12T:This course explores how scientific and technological advances in genetics have been presented in the movies
column5: focusing on American cinema. We will consider how selected films have influenced social perceptions of the role of scientists and genetic technologies in various areas. The movies and topics covered might include: The Black Stork (1917)
column7: Tomorrow’s Children (1934) for eugenics; The Boys from Brazil (1978)
column8: and Blueprint (2003) for human cloning; Jurassic Park (1993) for de-extinction or bringing extinct animal species back to life; Blade Runner (1982) for synthetic biology and human nature; Gattaca (1997) for human genetic enhancement; The Fly (1958) and The Island of Dr. Moreau (1996) for chimeras; My Sister’s Keeper (2009) for savior siblings; and Okja (2017) for genetically modified animals. We will also analyze the role of documentaries
column9: such as Human Nature (2019) and Make People Better (2022).:::::Social Science:

VIC274H1:Wisdom of the Social Sciences::24S:This course examines influential efforts to study human beings and society scientifically
column2: from the seventeenth century to the present. We consider major contributions from prominent thinkers
column6: and Sigmund Freud. We also review the contemporary relevance and persistent controversies about their ideas.:::::Social Science:

column1: VIC278H1:Modelling Evil and Disease::24S:Models frame our understanding and treatment of illness and are the most fundamental element of the scientific method. Theology
column3: and literature may use models in different ways than natural and medical sciences but fundamentally all modelling is an attempt to accurately predict and manipulate the future.:::::Humanities:
