column1: WDW151H1:Order and Disorder I: Issues and Perspectives::16T/24S:Societies require law and order
column2: but at what point does order become oppression? How do we balance our need for freedom and society’s need for order? This interdisciplinary seminar allows students to explore these and related questions through selected readings introducing theories from sociology
column5: and history. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: WDW152H1:Order and Disorder II: Problems and Solutions::16T/24S:This interdisciplinary seminar introduces students to some of the methods used by scholars and researchers in sociology
column6: and debate possible solutions to the problems of social order and disorder. Topics will vary from year to year. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Social Science:

column1: WDW195H1:From Page to Screen: Reading in the Digital Age::24L/12T:This course explores the practice of reading at the juncture between printed page and digital screen through assembling a digital commonplace book
column2: an annotated personal anthology that will document each student’s intellectual path. Students will learn close reading strategies
column4: and various modes of digital engagement with texts. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: WDW196H1:From Rayguns to Light Sabers: Science Fiction in Contemporary Culture::24S:This course examines science fiction as pop culture genre
column4: with attention to some of its key themes
column8: and its place in contemporary culture. We will study some works chosen by the class as well as by the instructor. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::ANT195H1

column1: WDW197H1:Jane Austen on Film::24S:In the 21st century
column2: Jane Austen’s early 19th-century novels of love and marriage are increasingly experienced through retellings and updatings in theatrical and made-for-television movies. The course will examine highlights from the last 25 years of Austen adaptations for what they can tell us about relationships in our time
column3: including how Austen’s stories are rewritten to please a modern audience. Films in the course will include works from 1995 to 2016 (from 1995
column5: Austen’s Emma retold as a Hollywood high school comedy and starring Alicia Silverstone; and Sense and Sensibility
column6: for which Emma Thompson’s screenplay won an Academy Award; and from 2016
column7: the Hallmark Channel’s Unleashing Mr. Darcy
column8: Austen’s Pride and Prejudice transferred to the present-day dog show circuit; and writer/director Whit Stillman’s Love and Friendship
column9: the first-ever film version of Austen’s Lady Susan). Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: WDW198H1:There and Back Again: Exploring Tolkien::24S:Since the mid-twentieth century
column2: J.R.R. Tolkien’s The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings have become classics of children’s and fantasy literature. In this course
column3: we read Tolkien’s The Lord of the Rings and investigate the world-building and imagined history that lies behind the books. We trace how Tolkien’s own life experience informed his work—his experience as a soldier of the Great War and a civilian during World War Two; as a scholar of medieval language and literature
column4: and of fairy tales; as a Catholic thinker; and as a lover of nature and the past. We also survey the afterlife of the novels in fantasy
column6: and the popular imagination. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

column1: WDW199H1:Indigenous Knowledge and Storytelling in Toronto::12T/24S:The land now known as Toronto has a 13
column2: 000+ year old history of Indigenous presence that is still unfolding. This history is inscribed in the land – it is visible in the geographical features
column4: and contemporary urban form of the city and is represented through stories (oral and written) told by diverse members of Toronto’s Indigenous community. This course engages with stories of Indigenous history and presence in Toronto through a selection of Indigenous literary works about Toronto
column6: and a series of experiential Indigenous storytelling tours of significant locations across the city. Students will be introduced to Indigenous worldviews and ways of knowing and will learn why storytelling remains a significant and culturally-appropriate means for keeping and sharing land-based Indigenous Knowledge. Students will gain a deeper appreciation of the city as a traditional Indigenous territory and will reflect on their own relationships and responsibilities within these lands. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:::::Humanities:

Participants will build upon the readings to create their own decolonial environmental justice future projects.:2.5 WGS credits including  WGS160Y1 and 1.0 WGS credit at the 300+ level:::WGS463H1 (Advanced Topics in Gender Theory: Toxic Worlds

column11: and trans communities. Through scaffolded assignments students will learn to write thesis statements that embrace complexity and use scholarly evidence to support their arguments. Readings include academic and non-academic prose from a variety of disciplines.:Completion of 4.0 credits:::INI203H1
WRR211H1:Introduction to Creative Writing::36S:This introductory course focuses on the process and craft of creative writing. Students will study short fiction
column2: creative nonfiction and poetry by established writers
column3: and learn to respond to works-in-progress by their peers. A variety of activities will help students generate
column5: and revise a portfolio of original creative work.:Completion of 4.0 credits:::INI211H1:Humanities:

column1: WRR300H1:Strategic Writing in Business and the Professions: Theory and Practice::36S:Students learn the theory and practice of effective and ethical communication in the workplace
column4: and non-profit organizations. Students apply ethical reasoning models to case studies. Students have an opportunity to work directly with a community partner
column5: helping them to solve an industry-specific problem or concern. This experiential learning enables students to work together as a team to develop relevant solutions as they strengthen their written and verbal communication skills.:Completion of 4.0 credits:::INI300H1

column1: WRR302H1:Writing in Business and the Professions for Rotman Commerce Students::24L/12T:Designed for and restricted to Rotman Commerce undergraduates
column2: the course reflects the program’s learning goals
column5: and business and professional communication (oral and written). Students apply business communication theory and ethical reasoning models to business cases. Students have an opportunity to work directly with a community partner
column6: helping them to solve an industry-specific problem or concern. This experiential learning enables students to work together as a team to develop relevant solutions as they strengthen their written and verbal communication skills:Completion of 4.0 credits:::INI300H1

column1: WRR303H1:Digital Rhetoric::36S:Examines the profound impact of digital media on contemporary culture and discourse. Students will explore recent currents in rhetoric and digital media. Students will investigate the rhetorical operation of digital media in domains ranging from academia to politics to popular culture. The class will analyze the role of rhetorical principles
column3: in a diverse array of online discourse such as discussion forums

column1: WRR304H1:The Illusion and Reality of Evidence::24L:This seminar in critical reading
column3: and writing focuses on the nature
column5: and the use and abuse of evidence in the process of formulating and supporting an argument. The case study method will be employed to assess the level of authority
column7: and objectivity evident in public discourse

column1: WRR305H1:Word and Image in Modern Writing::36S:This course examines the persuasive power of writing about visual art and texts. Students will analyze a variety of texts about visual images from several disciplines and genres: journalism
WRR308H1:Selected Topics in Writing and Rhetoric::24S:Courses on selected topics in Writing and Rhetoric.:Completion of 4.0 credits::::Humanities:

WRR310H1:Stylistic Editing and Copy Editing::36S:This course introduces students to professional editorial conventions at two later stages of the editorial process. Both stages require analytical skills and sentence expertise. Through stylistic editing
column2: students learn how to improve a writer’s literary style; through copy editing
column3: they learn how to ensure both accuracy and consistency (editorial style).:Completion of 4.0 credits:::INI310H1:Humanities:

column1: WRR311Y1:Seminar in Creative Writing::72S:This workshop course examines methodological approaches to literary fiction from the perspective of the creator. Through course readings
column4: student writers will learn how prose writers combine stylistic techniques
column9: and structure to produce literary effects.:Completion of 4.0 credits.::Experience or strong interest in writing fiction.:INI311Y1:Humanities:

column1: WRR312H1:Writing Literary Journalism::36L:This course introduces students to works by some of the most influential literary journalists of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. Classes will be devoted to individual literary-journalistic genres: the personal essay
column6: and cultural criticism. Students will look closely at key writers who worked across these genres: George Orwell
column9: Joyce Carol Oates. Over the semester
column10: students will develop and write a feature-length work of literary journalism in a genre of their choice
column11: to be refined through peer workshop and instructor feedback.:Completion of 4.0 credits::Experience or strong interest in writing journalism.:INI308H1 (Selected Topics in Writing and Rhetoric: Writing Literary Journalism)

column1: WRR313H1:Visual Rhetoric::36L:This course examines how images and objects communicate with and persuade viewers. Visual rhetoric is part of the broader academic field known as rhetorical studies. This course will introduce students to the “language” of display
column2: exploring questions such as the following: How does physical arrangement
column4: and architectural space give voice to the silent object? How are fine art and decorative art objects invested with meaning? Students will be introduced to object-based learning and material culture and learn to analyze and interpret visual grammar in international exhibitions
column7: and in museum collections. Objects will include ceramics
column13: and twentieth centuries.:Completion of 4.0 credits::WRR103H1/  WRR203H1/  WRR204H1:INI413H1

column1: WRR314H1:Writing for Social Change: A Community-Engaged Learning Experience::12L:How might we write to empower individuals and their communities to act towards social change? This community-engaged learning course uses theories of social change and persuasion to examine a variety of genres. Through collaboration with a campus or other community partner
column2: students will apply their academic learning and skills to writing-related projects that address human and community needs in a reciprocal manner. Activities and reflections will provide opportunities for students to strengthen critical thinking and communicative competencies. Writing projects may involve composing texts in multimodal and/or digital forms.:Completion of 4.0 credits:::INI414H1

column1: WRR316H1:Developmental and Substantive Editing::36S:This course introduces professional editorial conventions at two early stages of the editorial process. Both stages require editors to think critically and creatively as they assess content
column3: and argument. Students learn how to analyze and evaluate these elements
column5: and explain these suggestions persuasively.:Completion of 4.0 credits:::INI316H1:Humanities:
